Team USA remains stacked with talent, including Stephen Curry, LeBron James, and others. Durant's injury is classified as minor, with hopes of him joining the team for the Olympics.\n\nWith many teams around the world scratching and clawing to earn an Olympic berth, Team USA is already busy preparing for Paris by holding training camp in Las Vegas. However, while Team USA is stacked with superstars, they will be without arguably the best player on the roster early on, with a recent report from Shams Charania and Joe Vardon of The Athletic indicating Kevin Durant will miss the start of training camp because of a calf injury.\n\n\"We're just going to use an abundance of caution. It's not bad. He's assuring me it's not bad. We're just going to be really careful and take it day by day.\" - Steve Kerr\n\nThe Phoenix Suns' All-Star finished the 2023-24 campaign by averaging 27.1 points, 6.6 rebounds, 5.0 assists, and 1.2 blocks while shooting 41.3 percent from behind the arc. While those numbers are remarkable, what's more impressive is that Durant appeared in 75 games during the regular season, his most since 2018-19 while he was still a member of the Golden State Warriors.\n\nFortunately, Durant's ailment has been classified as \"minor,\" so there isn't any real concern he won't be in the lineup when Team USA opens up their quest for gold against Serbia on July 28. Still, Durant's health will be monitored closely heading toward the Olympics.\n\nTeam USA Is Stacked Even if Durant Misses The Olympics, Team USA Has Plenty of Talent\n\nFor now, there's a good chance Team USA's all-time leading scorer won't be available against Canada in an exhibition contest on Wednesday. But even if Durant can't play, teams have time before final rosters must be submitted, meaning there's still hope he'll be ready to roll when the Olympics commence in Paris in just a few short weeks.\n\nRest assured, even without Durant, Team USA isn't short of talent. The club features other future Hall of Famers like Stephen Curry and LeBron James. In addition, guys like Anthony Edwards, Tyrese Haliburton, Devin Booker, and Jayson Tatum will be mainstays in the NBA for years to come.\n\nAnd as discouraging as Durant's injury is, there have been some positive developments.\n\nJoel Embiid, who was limited to only 39 games in 2023-24, has been practicing. The same is true for Kawhi Leonard, who battled a knee injury of his own throughout the postseason.\n\nWith that said, Team USA is still a favorite without Durant, although America's chances of winning a gold medal will significantly decrease without him.\n\nRelated Anthony Edwards Believes He's the 'Number One Option' on Team USA\n\nDespite being loaded with talent, Anthony Edwards believes {"uri": "2024-07-415786988", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "05:52:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T05:52:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T03:51:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://fadeawayworld.net/joel-embiid-reacts-playing-alongside-stephen-curry-team-usa", "title": "Joel Embiid Reacts To Playing Alongside Stephen Curry For Team USA", "body": "Joel Embiid is surrounded by the world's best NBA players on Team USA, his first international camp with the national team. The greatness of the players around him is sinking in, with Embiid using Stephen Curry as an example of a generational talent who has made the game much easier for him on the national team.\n\n\"When you play with some of the greatest players of all time, it's fun. You gotta adjust, you gotta learn how to play. Everybody here has a high basketball IQ, so it's easy. When you play with someone like Steph, all you gotta do is free him up and he's either going to be wide-open or attack and make space for me and everybody else. The same thing with LeBron. It's really fun, and myself too, I'm trying to make it easy for them.\"\n\nEmbiid announced his intention to play for Team USA at the 2024 Olympics last October, with Fadeaway World getting Rudy Gobert's live reaction to the news after he and other members of France tried recruiting Embiid to represent their country at Paris 2024.\n\nJoel has had the luxury of playing alongside some of the best talents in the NBA, but nothing to the caliber of what he's seeing around him at Team USA. The top names on the roster are NBA legends who will be remembered as among the greatest of all time, especially LeBron James and Stephen Curry, who are both considered to be top-10 all-time players.\n\nEmbiid averaged 34.7 points, 11.0 rebounds, and 5.6 assists last season, struggling to stay healthy and playing just 39 games on the year. He's healthy for Team USA where he's expected to be the team's starting center ahead of options like Anthony Davis and Bam Adebayo.\n\nTeam USA Has A Colorful Group Of Characters\n\nThe 2024 Team USA team might not have a catchy nickname like the Dream Team or the Redeem Team, even though many have called this squad the 'Avengers.' This is among the greatest on-paper rosters Team USA has ever put together, with bonafide Hall of Famers in the mix along with future superstars who will be expected to carry the USA project by the time the 2028 Olympics rolls around.\n\nAlong with legends like Steph, LeBron, and Kevin Durant, the team has veteran superstars such as Anthony Davis and Kawhi Leonard, along with recent NBA Champions Jayson Tatum and Jrue Holiday. Funnily, the last time Holiday won a title was also in an Olympic year, with him playing a crucial role in helping the USA seal Gold.\n\nAnthony Edwards is among the most fascinating characters in the NBA today. He has already made bold public statements such as declaring himself as Team USA's no. 1 option while not even having locked down a starting spot. At the same time, he's deferring to legends like Durant because of the respect he has for them.\n\nEmbiid is fulfilling a lifelong dream by representing Team USA at the biggest stage of international basketball; The Olympics. This team cannot afford to come home with anything less than a Gold medal, otherwise, it may be remembered as one of the biggest failures in Team USA's history.\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. {"uri": "8219017522", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:54:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:54:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:53:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/fadeaway-world-nba/ranking-2024-team-usa-players-into-four-different-tiers/article_e73136c4-52f1-5515-81b1-c115f7c6dd64.html", "title": "Ranking 2024 Team USA Players Into Four Different Tiers", "body": "Team USA has one of the most impressive rosters we have ever seen assembled. LeBron James, Kevin Durant, and Stephen Curry form a dynamic trio of leaders that will bring on board a crew including Joel Embiid, Anthony Edwards, and Anthony Davis. Team USA has enough star power to be named the favorites in the 2024 Olympics and time will tell if they can get over the line and destroy the competition en route to the gold medal. Before the Americans get their Olympics started, it is time to divide all 12 players into four different tiers.\n\nUpdate: Kawhi Leonard withdraws from Team USA for the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nThe Biggest Stars\n\nLeBron James, Kevin Durant, Stephen Curry\n\nThe presence of LeBron James, Kevin Durant, and Stephen Curry on the 2024 Team USA roster brings together three of the most iconic players in modern basketball. LeBron James, at the age of 39, is aiming to secure his third gold medal, which would tie him with Carmelo Anthony for the second-most golds in USA Basketball history. His leadership and all-around game will be crucial for the team, providing a stabilizing force on and off the court.\n\nKevin Durant, already a three-time gold medalist, has the unique opportunity to become the first player in history to win four Olympic gold medals in basketball. His scoring prowess and versatility make him a constant threat and a cornerstone for Team USA's offensive schemes. Stephen Curry, seeking his first Olympic gold, brings unmatched shooting ability and playmaking skills that can break open any game, making this trio a formidable foundation for the team's success.\n\nLeBron, Durant, and Curry are not just seasoned veterans; they are transcendent talents who have dominated the NBA for over a decade. Their collective experience and basketball IQ are unparalleled, offering Team USA a blend of leadership, skill, and competitive spirit that few teams in the world can match. While all three are in the latter stages of their careers, their motivation to add to their legacies with another Olympic gold will be a driving force. This trio's ability to elevate their teammates and perform in high-pressure situations makes them invaluable assets as Team USA aims for gold in Paris.\n\nPerfect Roles\n\nAnthony Davis, Jrue Holiday, Derrick White\n\nAnthony Davis, Jrue Holiday, and Derrick White are perfectly suited for their roles on Team USA, providing balance and complementing the star power around them. Anthony Davis, a dominant force on both ends of the court, will benefit from his established chemistry with LeBron James and the elite scorers around him. Davis's ability to protect the rim, run the floor, and finish plays makes him an indispensable part of the team, particularly in transition and defensive setups.\n\nJrue Holiday, one of the best defensive guards in the league, fits seamlessly into Team USA's lineup as a utility player. His ability to play lockdown defense against opposing guards and wings, combined with his playmaking skills, makes him a valuable asset in various lineups. Holiday's unselfish play and versatility allow him to blend well with the stars around him, providing stability and support both on and off the ball.\n\nDerrick White, the strongest candidate to replace Kawhi Leonard, is a similar type of player to Jrue Holiday in terms of playing defense, moving the ball, and using his championship experience this year with the Celtics to help Team USA. White won't be unhappy with not receiving much of the plaudits or minutes and can do an exceptional role off the bench.\n\nTogether, Davis, Holiday, and White form a core that enhances Team USA's defensive tenacity and complements the offensive firepower of their superstar teammates.\n\nRelated: Team USA vs. France: 2024 Olympics (Analysis, Advantages, Who Is Better?)\n\nMust Prove Themselves\n\nJayson Tatum, Anthony Edwards, Joel Embiid, Devin Booker\n\nJayson Tatum, Anthony Edwards, Joel Embiid, and Devin Booker come into the 2024 Olympics with something to prove. Tatum, despite being a key player for the Boston Celtics, needs to demonstrate that he can be a true superstar on the international stage and lead Team USA to success.\n\nAnthony Edwards, after a disappointing fourth-place finish in the 2023 FIBA World Cup, faces pressure to show that he is an elite player capable of performing under the brightest lights. His explosive scoring and athleticism will be crucial, but consistency and leadership will determine his impact on the team.\n\nJoel Embiid, who recently chose to represent Team USA after gaining citizenship, must validate his decision and earn his place on the roster amid some skepticism after there were rumors he would join France. His dominant presence in the paint and ability to stretch the floor can be game-changing, but he needs to prove that he can stay healthy and adapt to the international game.\n\nDevin Booker, a gold medalist from the 2020 Olympics, has the task of solidifying his status as the best shooting guard in the NBA. With competition from Anthony Edwards for minutes, Booker must showcase his scoring ability and defensive improvements to maintain his role and contribute significantly to the team's success.\n\nHappy To Be Here\n\nBam Adebayo, Tyrese Haliburton\n\nBam Adebayo and Tyrese Haliburton are integral parts of Team USA, even if they are not the primary stars. Adebayo, known for his defensive prowess and high basketball IQ, will provide crucial depth behind Anthony Davis and Joel Embiid. His versatility in defending multiple positions and ability to facilitate offense from the center position makes him a valuable asset, even if he isn't the first option. Adebayo will relish the opportunity to go for his second gold medal (his first in 2020), contributing wherever needed and supporting the team's defensive efforts.\n\nTyrese Haliburton, coming off a fourth-place finish in the 2023 World Cup, is eager to prove he can perform on the biggest stage. His playmaking ability, combined with his efficient scoring, makes him a versatile guard who can fit in various lineups. While he may not be the focal point, Haliburton's contributions will be vital in ensuring Team USA's depth and cohesion throughout the tournament.\n\nTeam USA Is Primed For A Sweep Of The Competition En Route To Gold\n\nTeam USA enters the 2024 Olympics as the overwhelming favorite to not only win the gold medal but to do so in a dominant fashion, reminiscent of the legendary 1992 Dream Team. With an elite mix of superstar power, including LeBron James, Kevin Durant, and Stephen Curry, the team boasts an unparalleled level of talent and experience. These veterans, driven by the prospect of one final gold medal before they retire, provide leadership and a winning mentality that is crucial for success on the international stage.\n\nThe roster's depth is further bolstered by the perfect role players like Anthony Davis, Jrue Holiday, and Derrick White who offer defensive prowess and versatility. The addition of Joel Embiid, alongside rising stars like Jayson Tatum and Anthony Edwards, ensures that Team USA has no weaknesses. While formidable opponents such as Serbia, Greece, France, and Canada present strong challenges, Team USA's comprehensive advantages in skill, experience, and depth make them the team to beat. With all elements in place, Team USA is primed for a flawless run to Olympic gold.\n\nRelated: LeBron James Voted As Best Player At Team USA\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. If you liked this article, please consider following us on Google News. {"uri": "8215852904", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "20:21:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T20:21:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T20:20:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/team-usa-basketball-roster-schedule-for-2024-olympics-as-lebron-james-kevin-durant-more-eye-gold-in-paris/", "title": "Team USA basketball roster, schedule for 2024 Olympics as LeBron James, Kevin Durant, more eye gold in Paris - CBSSports.com", "body": "Star-studded Team USA has opened training camp and will play five tune-up games before the Olympics Getty Images\n\nThe men's Olympic basketball tournament field is now set, and we've got a crystal-clear picture of all three groups that will be competing in Paris later this month. Team USA will be in Group C, along with Serbia, Puerto Rico and South Sudan. Even with the United States already being heavily favored to win gold in Paris, that is made even easier by the group of opponents they'll face in the first stage before the knockout rounds.\n\nThe United States automatically qualified for the Paris Olympics by finishing as one of the top two countries in the Americas zone at the FIBA World Cup last summer. Team USA finished fourth after losing the bronze medal match against Canada. It was a shocking finish for the American men's team, and no doubt led to an increased interest in competing in the 2024 Olympics by top American talent in the NBA.\n\nIt led to perhaps the most stacked roster for Team USA in quite some time, but with that comes outsized expectations, too. The men's tournament begins on July 27, with Team USA taking the court for the first time on July 2. But prior to that, the United States will take part in a USA Basketball Showcase from July 10-22, where they team will play against five different countries as a tune-up for the Olympics. It'll feature matchups against Canada, Australia, Serbia, South Sudan and Germany.\n\nTeam USA will be led by Warriors head coach Steve Kerr, as well as Gonzaga head coach Mark Few, Clippers coach Ty Lue and Heat coach Erik Spoelstra as assistants.\n\nAs we get closer to the start of the Olympics, here's all the information you need to know about Team USA's roster, schedule and an outlook for the defending world champions.\n\nTeam USA roster PlayerPositionNBA team\n\nBam Adebayo\n\nCenter\n\nMiami Heat\n\nDevin Booker\n\nGuard\n\nPhoenix Suns\n\nStephen Curry\n\nGuard\n\nGolden State Warriors\n\nAnthony Davis\n\nForward/Center\n\nLos Angeles Lakers\n\nKevin Durant\n\nForward\n\nPhoenix Suns\n\nAnthony Edwards\n\nGuard\n\nMinnesota Timberwolves\n\nJoel Embiid\n\nCenter\n\nPhiladelphia 76ers\n\nTyrese Haliburton\n\nGuard\n\nIndiana Pacers\n\nJrue Holiday\n\nGuard\n\nBoston Celtics\n\nLeBron James\n\nForward\n\nLos Angeles Lakers\n\nKawhi Leonard\n\nForward\n\nLos Angeles Clippers\n\nJayson Tatum\n\nForward\n\nBoston Celtics\n\nTeam USA Basketball Showcase scheduleOpponentDateTime (EST)LocationTV/Streaming\n\nCanada\n\nJuly 10\n\n10:30 p.m.\n\nLas Vegas\n\nFS1/fubo\n\nAustralia\n\nJuly 15\n\n12 p.m.\n\nAbu Dhabi\n\nFS1/fubo\n\nSerbia\n\nJuly 17\n\n12 p.m.\n\nAbu Dhabi\n\nFS1/fubo\n\nSouth Sudan\n\nJuly 20\n\n3 p.m.\n\nLondon\n\nFOX/fubo\n\nGermany\n\nJuly 22\n\n3 p.m.\n\nLondon\n\nFOX/fubo\n\nTeam USA 2024 Olympics scheduleOpponentDateTime (EST)Phase\n\nSerbia\n\nJuly 28\n\n11:15 a.m.\n\nGroup stage\n\nSouth Sudan\n\nJuly 31\n\n3 p.m.\n\nGroup stage\n\nPuerto Rico\n\nAug. 3\n\n11:15 a.m.\n\nGroup stageTBDAug. 6TBDQuarterfinalsTBDAug. 8TBDSemifinalsTBDAug. 10TBDGold/Bronze Medal gamesTeam USA outlook\n\nThe United States has won 16 gold medals at the Olympics, and has captured nothing less than gold since 2004. The Americans enter every Olympic Games as the heavy favorites, and for good reason. They field the best players every four years, and despite putting together a team on a short timespan they still typically manage to bulldoze the competition every four years. But Team USA isn't infallible. In each of the two last FIBA World Cup appearances, the U.S. failed to medal, placing fourth last summer and an even more shocking seventh-place finish in 2019. Granted, those teams did not boast the best talent the United States has to offer, but it's proof that you can't just throw anyone out there with hopes of beating the rest of the world.\n\nBut the 2024 Olympic roster is perhaps the best collection of talent the United States has fielded since the 2008 Redeem Team, which was built to avenge a bronze medal finish at the 2004 Games. We'll get Stephen Curry in his first Olympics ever. Probably the last Olympic appearance from LeBron James, the debut of Joel Embiid, who Team USA was hotly recruiting to join instead of going with France or Cameroon. And peppered in there is a nice blend of older talent like Kevin Durant, Kawhi Leonard, Jrue Holiday and Anthony Davis, mixed with the next generation of American stars like Anthony Edwards, Jayson Tatum and Tyrese Haliburton.\n\nHowever, the field at the 2024 Olympics features some of the best international players that will all be chomping at the bit to try and knock the Americans off. Canada has the second-best collection of NBA talent behind the United States, and could very well meet the U.S. in the gold medal match. The same is true of France, which will have Victor Wembanyama and Rudy Gobert patrolling the frontcourt. Even in Team USA's own group, the team will have to face reigning NBA MVP Nikola Jokic and Serbia, which finished second at last summer's World Cup. And then there's Puerto Rico, which earned a berth to the Olympics for the first time since 2004. The last time Puerto Rico were there, the country handed Team USA a shocking loss in the group stage, which sent the Americans on a spiral that resulted in a bronze medal finish.\n\nThe Americans will certainly be favored in every matchup, but they can't afford to take any opponent lightly as there's NBA players on nearly every roster heading to Paris. The biggest weakness for Team USA will be figuring out how to play together on both sides of the floor. They have training camp and five tune-up games to build chemistry, but it's always a little clunky when you have 12 guys who are not used to playing together.", "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", {"uri": "8219044760", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:11:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:11:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:11:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/au/nba/news/usa-basketball-starting-lineup-projection-olympics/d4d5902740771d8f024bf9ae", "title": "USA Olympic basketball starting lineup projection: Why Jrue Holiday is best option with Stephen Curry, LeBron James", "body": "Team USA has an embarrassment of riches on its roster in its quest for a gold medal in the 2024 Olympics.\n\nAll 12 members have made an All-Star team, four have won an MVP and they've already won a combined 10 Olympic gold medals. Picking out a starting five is a tough but important task.\n\nPure talent isn't enough to win international competitions anymore. The rest of the world has closed the gap on America. Look no further than last summer's FIBA World Cup, where Team USA finished in fourth place despite bringing All-Stars like Anthony Edwards, Tyrese Haliburton and Jalen Brunson.\n\nFinding the group that fits the best together will determine how far Team USA goes in this tournament. Here is their best starting five.\n\nMORE: Why Kawhi Leonard is withdrawing from Team USA for the Olympics\n\nCurry should be one of the first guys who makes it into the starting lineup. This is his first chance at playing for an Olympic gold, but there shouldn't be much of an adjustment period for him. He's the best shooter in the world, and that will translate to any level of basketball. He's also very familiar with the sets that coach Steve Kerr will install.\n\nHoliday isn't the second-best guard on the team, but he's the best fit next to Curry. He can take on tougher defensive assignments that are necessary in the more physical style of international basketball. He embraced that role during the Tokyo Olympics, closing out games for Team USA to help win gold.\n\nHoliday's offense is perfect for this team as well. The starting lineup doesn't need shot creators. Rather, it needs a few role players who can cut well and shoot from 3.\n\nHoliday is one of the best corner 3-point shooters in the NBA, hitting an astounding 60 percent of his looks last season, per Cleaning the Glass. And his off-ball movement was the key in helping the Celtics win a championship.\n\nMORE: Ranking all 12 players on USA Olympics basketball roster\n\nDurant has been one of the best players for Team USA in its history. He's won three gold medals and is first all-time with 435 points. We already know that his game translates well to the Olympics. He's been one of the most clutch players in the world in those settings, helping to close out tight games several times.\n\nJames has a ton of experience himself, winning two golds and one bronze. He's first all-time with 88 assists and is coming off an NBA season in which he made Third Team All-NBA.\n\nHaving LeBron and KD as the forwards provides a very important advantage for Team USA. Scoring has not been a problem. They have lost previous international tournaments because of a lack of size and rebounding.\n\nOffensive rebounds are a much bigger part of international play. LeBron and KD are big and strong enough to keep other forwards off the glass, and they even offer great weak-side rim protection.\n\nMORE: Tyrese Haliburton ready to meet gold standard set by USA Basketball at Olympics\n\nEmbiid is the easy option to start for Team USA. He's the most talented center of the group, the best shooter, has the most size and is also an elite shot blocker.\n\nThat size will be even more valuable in the Olympics, which plays without a defensive three-second rule. Embiid can stay parked right under the rim on defense, where he is incredibly valuable at deterring layups.\n\nAmerica lost in the World Cup last year in large part due to the ineffectiveness of its centers. Jaren Jackson Jr. couldn't grab a rebound to save his life. That won't be a problem for Embiid, who averaged 11.0 rebounds per game in 2023-24.\n\nEmbiid gives this starting lineup five good-to-great shooters, allowing Kerr to play a five-out offensive style and lean into how unstoppable all of his players can be with good spacing. That gives Team USA not only its best lineup but one of the best that it's ever had for any Olympics.", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sporting News"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-07-416992534", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "06:01:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T06:01:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T05:31:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/olympics-news-steve-kerr-reveals-warriors-inspired-plan-for-stephen-curry-on-team-usa", "title": "Steve Kerr reveals Warriors-inspired plan for Stephen Curry on Team USA", "body": "Life is so much easier for Steve Kerr as the head coach of Team USA with longtime Warriors star Stephen Curry on the team.\n\nSteve Kerr's first year as the head coach of Team USA did not go according to plan. They finished in fourth during their 2023 FIBA World Cup run in Manila, which, suffice to say, is a huge disappointment, as it's always gold medal or bust for the most stacked basketball nation in the world. With redemption in the 2024 Paris Olympics as their main goal, the national team committee brought in the heavy hitters, such as LeBron James, Stephen Curry, and Kevin Durant.\n\nKerr and Curry, in particular, go way back; the two have been at the heart of the Golden State Warriors' dynasty that was built at the start of the 2014-15 season. They are 10 years into their partnership -- which is both a frightening reminder of how fast time flies and a helpful nuggets for Team USA's bid to reclaim international basketball supremacy.\n\nIn particular, Steve Kerr plans to utilize all his years of experience in coaching Stephen Curry to bring out the best in him, featuring him heavily in Team USA's playbook with a slew of plays straight from the Warriors' bag.\n\n\"Having Steph on the team is fantastic for a number of reasons. He's obviously a brilliant player, but the comfort level that we have together. We'll run some of the actions we run in Golden State for him. He's very familiar with everything we're doing,\" Kerr told reporters, per NBC Sports Warriors via ClutchPoints Twitter (X).\n\nSteve Kerr clarified that Stephen Curry's impact stretches beyond the tactics they have drawn up on the board. Curry has a level of trust in Kerr thanks to their decade-long partnership with the Warriors that would then help get the rest of Team USA on the same page.\n\n\"But it's not just Xs and Os. He's one of our leaders. For me to have the ear of one of our leaders, and vice versa, I think it helps the communication process with the rest of the team,\" Kerr added.\n\nIt will certainly be a delight for Kerr to have the services of the greatest off-ball player of all time, someone whom opposing defenses cannot leave at any time. Stephen Curry's game-breaking gravity and unselfishness makes him the perfect fit for Team USA, and Kerr will be doing a disservice for everyone if he doesn't maximize Curry's skillset by deploying some Warriors-exclusive strategies.\n\nCould this be the best iteration of Team USA ever?\n\nCalling any other version of Team USA aside from the 1992 Dream Team as the best ever may seem blasphemous, and for good reason. That 1992 squad destroyed every team that came in their way of achieving the gold medal in Barcelona. But since then, there have been great basketball advancements all over the globe, closing the gap between the United States and the world in terms of talent and skill level.\n\nThe 2024 version of Team USA might be the most stacked it has been since 1992; this team will be having the services of four former MVPs in Stephen Curry, LeBron James, Kevin Durant, and Joel Embiid. Curry, James, and Durant may be on the wrong side of 30, with James even turning 40 later this year, but in terms of basketball pedigree at the time of Olympic representation, this 2024 team may be unmatched.\n\nThe 1992 Dream Team only had three MVPs at the time of the Olympic Games (Michael Jordan, Larry Bird, and Magic Johnson). However, Bird was retired from the NBA by this time, and Johnson only came out of retirement following after he had contracted HIV. Simply put, Bird and Johnson were not exactly the players they once were in 1992.\n\nOf course, it's hard to view Curry, James, and Durant as being in their primes. But they are still playing at an incredibly high level, no ifs or buts.\n\nCurry averaged 26/5/5 for the Warriors last season, James was voted as the best player in Team USA training camp following a season in which he averaged 25/7/8, and Durant was still one of the best scorers in the association last year as he put up 27/7/5 on a nightly basis. Joel Embiid scored 34.7 points a night last season, and him being in the middle for Team USA gives them one of the most formidable scorers in world basketball.\n\nThis is without even mentioning four NBA champions that the 2024 team has in Kawhi Leonard, Jayson Tatum, Anthony Davis, and Jrue Holiday. (The 1992 team had no other champions aside from Jordan, Bird, Johnson, and Scottie Pippen.) The 2024 Team USA squad also doesn't have a token member like the 1992 team did in Christian Laettner.\n\nOnly time will tell, of course, if the 2024 version of Team USA steamrolls opponents the way the 1992 squad did. 32 years ago in Barcelona, Team USA won by an average of 43.8 points, and they didn't even see the need to call a timeout once. But they certainly have the talent and the fit to replicate or even surpass that level of dominance.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ClutchPoints"}, "authors": The last time he was a member of Team USA was at the 2012 Olympics in London, where the United States also won gold.\n\nJames did not compete in the last two Olympics, but makes his return this year {"uri": "2024-07-417589817", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:50:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:50:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:46:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.covers.com/olympics/canada-vs-usa-predictions-picks-wednesday-7-10-2024", "title": "Canada vs USA Predictions, Picks & Odds - 7-10", "body": "Our Olympic basketball betting picks believe Team Canada will keep things much closer than the oddsmakers are expecting in their 40-minute exhibition clash with Team USA on Wednesday night.\n\nTeam USA and Team Canada are the Top 2 favorites to take home gold at the 2024 Paris Olympics. But before the tournament begins in earnest, they have a few tune-up exhibition games on the schedule, including a showdown between the two highly-touted North American sides in Las Vegas on Wednesday, July 10.\n\nI take you through my Canada vs. USA predictions and free betting picks as I explain why the Canadians could make this more competitive than oddsmakers believe.\n\nThe road to the Paris Olympics begins in Las Vegas tonight. Or at least it does for two of the teams with the greatest aspirations in the tournament in Team USA and Team Canada. While the Americans are big favorites to win the gold -- and their exhibition match against their northern neighbors on Wednesday -- both are far from a sure thing.\n\nThe world continues to catch up to Team USA when it comes to talent, and in recent years the Americans have proven much more vulnerable than their talent pool would suggest. After a close-run thing to capture gold in the Tokyo Olympics, Team USA failed to medal at the FIBA World Cup last year.\n\nIn part, that's because they sent their B-team in terms of star power. While a few key players from that fourth-placed finishing squad return -- including Anthony Edwards and Tyrese Haliburton -- the rest of the team is stocked with the most talented and decorated players in recent American basketball history.\n\nThey have arguably the best to ever do it in LeBron James, the most decorated men's Olympian in Kevin Durant, and first-time appearances by both Steph Curry and Joel Embiid just to name a few. While Durant is sidelined with a calf injury ahead of Wednesday's tilt, the rest of the team is a full go and should prove formidable.\n\nBut the other reason that American team didn't medal at FIBA is because Team Canada beat them in the Bronze Medal game. Canada has their own star power in the form of Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Jamal Murray, who form as good a one-two punch in the backcourt as any team in the tournament -- including Team USA -- can muster.\n\nTeam Canada also has a level of continuity that the Americans do not. While this American team is almost entirely different than the one that suited up for the FIBA World Cup, Canada is bringing back almost the same roster with the addition of Murray. Some members of Team USA have played with each other at the international level, and some are teammates, but this mix is one they'll still be working to figure out.\n\nThere is still a ton of uncertainty with Team USA's rotation, and they'll likely use these exhibition games to experiment.\n\nWho stars and who sacrifices is always a tricky dance that Team USA typically takes a few games to sort out. Brandon Ingram was in theory going to be among Team USA's leading players heading into last year's World Cup, but in the end figured very little as Jalen Brunson, Edwards, and Haliburton seized the reins.\n\nThe Canadians come in knowing their roles on both ends, and that should give them something of a leg up when it comes to competing with Team USA's overwhelming talent advantage.\n\nAnd while Team USA theoretically has the ability to play multiple styles with the depth of their roster, they're limited in style of play with their starters. With Embiid presumably getting the nod as the starting center, they will have to play a drop defense with perimeter players fighting over the screen.\n\nJrue Holiday is excellent at navigating those kinds of screens, but the rest of the American guards are certainly not. Canada can have whichever guard isn't guarded by Holiday play pick and roll, and attack Embiid in space.\n\nGilgeous-Alexander and Murray are among the few players who can beat teams strictly from the midrange area, so a drop defense is not going to slow them down as long as they have quality spacing.\n\nTeam USA are deserving favorites, but with some kinks to work out and some notable defensive limitations, I suspect the Canadians will at least keep things respectable on Wednesday.", "source": {"uri": "covers.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Covers.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": The United States didn't even score a medal in that tournament, as they lost to Canada in the bronze medal contest. {"uri": "8215580701", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "16:15:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T16:15:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T16:13:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.nba.com/news/trending-topics-team-usa-starters-paris-olympics", "title": "Trending Topics: Who should start for Team USA?", "body": "Will Kawhi Leonard (left) and LeBron James start for Team USA in Paris?\n\nPeriodically, NBA.com's writers will weigh in on key storylines or trending topics around the league.\n\nWhich five players should start for Team USA at the Paris Olympics?\n\nSteve Aschburner\n\nMight as well start the Legends. That starting lineup would boast 12 NBA rings and eight MVP trophies. But it also would stack up as 173 years old, an average age of 34.6 years. Pretty long in the tooth compared to some global rivals. Keep in mind the fabled 1992 Dream Team had only two guys aged 31 or older to this squad's seven. James, Curry and Durant already are older than Larry Bird and Magic Johnson were on their way out the door in '92. And the Dream Team's top five in minutes logged in those Barcelona Games averaged 28.6 years old. How will Team USA spell gold in Paris? \"Gee, old.\"\n\nBrian Martin\n\nHere are the five players I'd choose to start, but I'm just as interested in seeing Steve Kerr's closing lineup when Team USA gets challenged.\n\nAssuming good health (especially with KD missing some of training camp due to calf soreness), I would start the four NBA MVPs in Curry, LeBron, Durant and Embiid, with one spot up for grabs. After a lack of size hurt Team USA at the FIBA World Cup, Kerr could go with Anthony Davis next to Embiid and have three players at 6-foot-10 or taller on the frontline. Or he could go with a more traditional backcourt with Edwards, Devin Booker or Jrue Holiday next to Curry.\n\nWhile the US failed to medal at the World Cup, Kerr raved about Edwards all last summer. His two-way ability and elite athleticism will offer balance to a starting five featuring three players age 35 or older.\n\nThis is a little gimmicky, but also comes with some strategy.\n\nPutting Davis at the four obviously compromises the team's shooting, and I'd be a little nervous about James and Embiid as the primary defenders in a bunch of pick-and-rolls. But good luck scoring in the paint or grabbing any rebounds against five guys who are no shorter than 6-foot-8. Really, who starts doesn't matter. It's not that the United States is unbeatable, but rather that anybody on this roster could deserve to start (or close) games. It's about finding the right mix and the hot hands by the time they get to the quarterfinals on Aug. 6.\n\nMichael C. Wright\n\nDepth affords Team USA flexibility for creativity with various combinations based on situational needs, meaning the starting five likely won't be the group that winds up finishing games.\n\nThis group provides plenty of scoring as all five players in this lineup are virtually unguardable. Curry and James (a two-time gold medal winner) can handle facilitation duties in addition to scoring, and there's no way you keep an Olympics legend like Durant out of the starting five, if healthy, of course. A three-time Olympics gold medalist, Durant has led the competition in scoring average in 2012, 2016 and 2020 and ranks No. 1 in Team USA history for points (435), 3-pointers (74) and free throws {"uri": "8217953886", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "03:51:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T03:51:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T03:50:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://heavy.com/sports/olympics/projected-starting-lineup-for-team-usa-features-four-nba-mvps/", "title": "Projected Starting Lineup for Team USA Features Four NBA MVPs", "body": "Getty Team USA members LeBron James, Kevin Durant and Anthony Davis.\n\nFew events at the upcoming Olympics in Paris will have more eyes on it than men's basketball, with Team USA and its galaxy of basketball superstars at the forefront.\n\nFew people who cover basketball have a better feel for how a super team like this might come together than The Ringer's Bill Simmons, the author of the New York Times best-seller \"The Book of Basketball\" and co-creater of \"30 for 30\" on ESPN.\n\nSimmons recently took a stab at projecting Team USA's starting lineup on \"The Bill Simmons Podcast\" ahead of their opening game against Serbia on July 28.\n\nSimmons' projected starting lineup; Minnesota Timberwolves shooting guard Anthony Edwards, Golden State Warriors point guard Stephen Curry, Los Angeles Lakers forward LeBron James, Phoenix Suns forward Kevin Durant and Philadelphia 76ers center Joel Embiid.\n\nOut of that group, only Edwards has yet to win NBA Most Valuable Player honors. James is a four-time MVP, Curry a two-time MVP and Durant and Embiid have each won the award once.\n\nSince men's basketball became an Olympic sport in 1936, Team USA has won the gold medal 16 times, although the U.S. boycotted the Olympics in 1980 with a team that would have featured future NBA players like Isiah Thomas, Mark Aguirre, Buck Williams, Ronaldo Blackman and Sam Bowie.\n\nTeam USA's 1972 loss to the Soviet Union in the gold medal game is one of the most controversial finishes in sports history. The 1988 team won a bronze medal and led to the U.S. allowing pro basketball players to participate in the Olympics -- which the rest of the world was already doing -- beginning with the Dream Team in 1992.\n\nThe 2004 team, which was James' first foray into Olympic competition, also won the bronze medal and led to a revamping of the process of selecting the Olympic team and the Redeem Team in 2008 featuring Kobe Bryant, James, Dwyane Wade and Carmelo Anthony and was coached by former Duke head coach Mike Krzyewski.\n\nThe 2008 team defeated Spain and Hall of Fame center Pau Gasol, 118-107, for the gold medal.\n\nAlmost as a direct result of Team USA sending its NBA stars to the 1992 Olympics and every Olympics after that, basketball exploded on the international stage and we are seeing the results of that with a loaded field in the 2024 Olympics.\n\nEven with all that talent, the country that will almost certainly pose the biggest threat to Team USA in 2024 will almost certainly be Canada. The Canadians have a team unlike any in the country's history and features Nuggets guard and NBA champion Jamal Murray, Oklahoma City Thunder guard and two-time All-NBA selection Shai Gilgeous-Alexander along with more NBA talent like Andrew Wiggins, Luguentz Dort, Dillon Brooks, R.J. They will begin their Olympic campaign against Serbia on July 28. The Lebron James and Co. will then face South Sudan on July 31. However, the team has been dominant in the Olympics. {"uri": "2024-07-417653902", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:47:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:47:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.espn.co.uk/nba/story/_/id/40525757/team-usa-basketball-paris-olympics-first-lebron-curry-durant", "title": "'Enjoying every minute': What this Team USA run means for Curry, LeBron and KD", "body": "That's when, as Curry recalled, the two longtime NBA rivals spoke about the possibility of teaming up at the 2024 Paris Olympics and joining forces on arguably the greatest collection of talent in basketball history.\n\n\"He was the first person I talked to,\" Curry said Sunday afternoon of his conversation with James. \"'Would this be something I would want to do?' And from there it was like, 'Let's get it.'\"\n\nFor all that Curry, James and fellow future Hall of Famer Kevin Durant have achieved in their careers, they have yet to play together for Team USA. Curry played with Durant during gold medal runs in the 2010 and 2014 World Championships. James and Durant, meanwhile, won gold at the 2012 London Olympics.\n\nBut this summer, the trio of superstars, now deep into their 30s, will take the floor together in international play for the first time. But don't call it a \"last hurrah.\"\n\n\"Nah,\" Durant told ESPN with a smile, when asked if that was how he viewed finally pairing up with both James and Curry on this team. \"These guys are still playing at an elite level. I feel like Bron could play 4 or 5 more and be here in 2028 in [the Los Angeles Olympics]. Steph's still playing great ball. I'm doing all right, too.\n\n\"I don't want this to be a farewell tour or make it just about us three. It's about trying to win this fifth in a row.\"\n\nHeading into Wednesday's Olympics tuneup against Canada in Las Vegas (10:30 p.m. ET), Team USA is a heavy favorite to win that fifth straight gold medal -- in part because of the presence of the NBA's three biggest American stars. Durant can become the first man to claim four Olympic basketball gold medals, having been part of the past three winning Olympic teams. James, his 40th birthday on the horizon, can add a third gold medal to an already impressive international r\u00e9sum\u00e9.\n\nAnd then there's Curry, who, after 15 seasons in the NBA, is preparing for his Olympic debut.\n\n\"Yeah, it's really cool,\" Curry said. \"I've played with Team USA before on the world championship stage, but I don't know what to expect when it comes to this challenge and this experience. And so I had the first-practice jitters. I'm sure I'll have it for the game [Wednesday] just because I know it means so much. ...\n\n\"Add the surrealness of who is on this team and all the battles that we've had over the course of our careers and the fact that we get to put that energy together as teammates. So I'm enjoying every minute of this.\"\n\nA sense of awe has permeated throughout the first few days of Team USA training camp. Past Olympic rosters have boasted plenty of talent, but there's a reason this group has been compared -- at times favorably -- to the fabled 1992 Dream Team.\n\n\"Do you see this team?\" center Bam Adebayo, playing in his second Olympics after winning gold at the 2020 Tokyo Games, said Sunday. \"When you put [together] a team like this, and you get compared to, like, the Dream Team, it kind of puts it in perspective how great this team can be if we play the right way.\"\n\n\"We got LeBron, KD and Steph,\" Team USA first-timer Anthony Edwards said. \"So I don't feel like nobody can beat those three by themselves on the court.\n\n\"So I mean, you mix in two of us regular guys, we'll be all right.\"\n\nIt has been striking to see Curry and James finally sharing the court for Team USA after their historic playoff battles: four straight NBA Finals showdowns from 2015 to 2018 and again in the 2023 Western Conference semifinals, where James' Los Angeles Lakers knocked out Curry and the defending champion Golden State Warriors.\n\n\"It was like a healthy resentment of somebody that's standing in your way,\" Curry said of his playoff battles against James. \"But through it all, there's obviously the utmost respect for who he is as a person and player and like how good he is and the challenge of trying to beat him and trying to solve that problem every year.\"\n\nAdded James: \"I know how much he loves to win and how much he loves to be in competition. We've always had like these short moments like either All-Star Games or whatever the case may be, where we had these short pockets of time together and it's been super organic and easy.\"\n\nCurry, James and Durant have spent much of the past two decades fighting against one another for NBA supremacy. For the next six weeks, they'll play side by side and try to enjoy the process of the trio's first -- and possibly only -- Olympic run together on the international stage.\n\n\"I can't speak for those two guys, but for me it's going to be ecstatic excitement, a humbling wow factor,\" James told ESPN. \"The last 15, 17, 18 years, myself, Steph, KD, have been the talk of the NBA. ...\n\n\"We don't know how many more opportunities we're going to have to even play the game. So to be able to have this moment at this point in our careers is just super special.\"", "source": {"uri": "espn.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8219223466", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:33:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:33:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:33:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://cubuffs.com/news/2024/7/10/mens-basketball-derrick-white-named-to-2024-usa-basketball-mens-national-team", "title": "Derrick White Named to 2024 USA Basketball Men's National Team - University of Colorado Athletics", "body": "LAS VEGAS - USA Basketball has announced that Derrick White has been named to the 2024 USA Basketball Men's National Team, which will compete at the Olympic Games Paris 2024, set for July 26-Aug. 11, 2024. White was selected by USA Basketball Men's National Team managing director Grant Hill.\n\nAs previously confirmed Kawhi Leonard, who was named to the 2024 USA Men's National Team in April, will not participate at the Olympic Games. USA Basketball and the L.A. Clippers determined it's in Leonard's best interest to spend the remainder of the summer preparing for the upcoming NBA season.\n\n\"I am happy to announce that Derrick will compete at his first Olympic Games on the heels of a championship season in Boston,\" Hill said. \"We look forward to him joining the team in the coming days as we continue preparations for Paris.\n\n\"I want to thank Kawhi for his commitment to the USA Men's National Team. He earned the opportunity to represent the United States, but USA Basketball and Clippers leadership felt it's important to allow Kawhi to prepare for the NBA season.\"\n\nIn addition to White, the 2024 USA Men's National Team features Bam Adebayo (Miami Heat), Devin Booker (Phoenix Suns), Stephen Curry (Golden State Warriors), Anthony Davis (Los Angeles Lakers), Kevin Durant (Phoenix Suns), Anthony Edwards (Minnesota Timberwolves), Joel Embiid (Philadelphia 76ers), Tyrese Haliburton (Indiana Pacers), Jrue Holiday (Boston Celtics), LeBron James (Los Angeles Lakers) and Jayson Tatum (Boston Celtics).\n\nWhite, a seven-year NBA veteran, joins the USA Men's National Team after helping lead the Celtics to a record 18th NBA Championship in June. In 2023-24, the 30-year-old guard averaged 15.2 points, 5.2 assists and 4.2 rebounds and was named to the NBA All-Defensive Second Team for the second consecutive season.\n\nWhite was named to the 2024 USA Men's National Team player pool in January. He was a finalist for the 2020 USA Men's National Team and a member of the 2019 USA World Cup Team.\n\nAn All-Pac-12 Conference First Team performer for Colorado in 2016-17, White becomes the third former Buffalo to play for the USA Men's National Team at the Summer Olympics, joining Burdette Haldorson and Bob Jeangerard. A pair of CU Athletic Hall of Fame members, Haldorson and Jeangerard were teammates on USA's 1956 Gold Medal team in Melbourne. Haldorson also won Gold in Rome with the 1960 Team USA squad that was inducted into Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in 2010.\n\nThe 2024 Men's Senior National team boasts a combined 11 Olympic appearances and owns 10 Olympic gold medals as well as three FIBA World Cup titles. In total, the U.S. will take 11 NBA All-Stars, four NBA MVPs and seven NBA champions to Paris.\n\nThe 2024 USA Men's National Team is led by head coach Steve Kerr (Golden State Warriors), who is assisted by Mark Few (Gonzaga University), Tyronn Lue (LA Clippers) and Erik Spoelstra (Miami Heat).\n\nThe 2024 Olympic Games are set for July 26-Aug. 11. The U.S. men open group play in Lille, France, against Serbia on July 28. They will then face South Sudan on July 31 and Puerto Rico on Aug. 3.\n\nThe USA Basketball Showcase, an exhibition series to help prepare USA men's and women's national teams for international competition, will begin today, July 10, when the United States hosts Canada at T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas at 10:30 p.m. ET live on FS1.", "source": {"uri": "cubuffs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-07-415759913", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "05:17:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T05:17:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T05:00:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/au/nba/news/best-players-team-usa-olympic-roster-ranked/9a8fd02aff4ecf83e3efec02", "title": "Best players on Team USA, ranked: Where Stephen Curry, LeBron James & more land on 2024 Olympic basketball roster", "body": "The 2024 Paris Olympics are quickly approaching and USA Basketball has assembled one of its most talented men's rosters ever. Some are even saying it could be the most talented ever.\n\nRegardless of where this iteration of Team USA stands in the all-time conversation, the first matter of hand is the pursuit of a fifth consecutive Olympic gold medal. As the journey begins, Timberwolves guard Anthony Edwards, who is an Olympic first-timer, made headlines by proclaiming he'll be the team's No. 1 option.\n\nThe truth of the matter is that Team USA is talented enough to have a different No. 1 option depending on the pulse of that particular game, but there is likely a particular order in which head coach Steve Kerr and staff would prefer things to go.\n\nWho is the best player on this talented squad? Based on this past NBA season, the FIBA game and circumstance, The Sporting News attempts the near-impossible task of placing 12 of America's best in order.\n\nMORE: A'ja Wilson, Breanna Stewart headline star-studded USA women's basketball roster\n\nCurry's Olympic debut is sure to be a memorable one. With Golden State's Play-In Tournament elimination, Curry has had the benefit of an extended offseason to prepare for Paris.\n\nThe greatest shooter in the world playing with a shorter 3-point line will be scary for any team that faces Team USA. After shooting 40.8 percent on 11.8 3-point attempts per game in 2023-24, Curry should have a field day.\n\n2. Joel Embiid\n\nEmbiid will also benefit from having a long layoff after Philadelphia's early playoff exit. The FIBA game is beneficial for dominant big men and Embiid is just that. His value will be on full display throughout the Olympics as he'll be surrounded by players who complement his strengths.\n\nIt's easy to forget Embiid averaged 34.7 points in only 33.6 minutes per game in 2023-24.\n\n3. LeBron James\n\nIf this is the last Olympic hoorah for James, you can guarantee he'll make the most of it.\n\nJames, a two-time gold medalist and soon-to-be four-time Olympian, is somehow at the top of his game at 39. He'll be the floor general for a talented team that will benefit from his cerebral approach and playmaking abilities.\n\n4. Jayson Tatum\n\nOn the heels of an NBA title in June, Tatum looks to join the elite group of players to win a championship and Olympic gold in the same summer. After being the focal point of opposing defenses throughout the playoffs, the Celtics star can breathe easily, meaning the scoring should also come easily.\n\nMORE: How the Celtics' championship exemplifies sacrifice and Boston pride\n\n5. Anthony Davis\n\nIt's been 12 years since Davis took the floor on the Olympic stage but he now has an opportunity to apply the wisdom passed to him when he was a 19-year-old incoming rookie. Davis is a defensive mastermind and one of the game's most skilled players.\n\nDavis' rim protection and defensive prowess will be one of the keys to America having a chance to dominate.\n\n6. Kevin Durant\n\nDurant entered Olympic training camp hobbled by a calf injury, or else he'd jump higher on the list.\n\nOne of the purest scorers the game has ever seen, Durant has an opportunity to make it four consecutive gold medals. Even at 35, he still makes it look easy. The Olympics should be no different.\n\n7. Anthony Edwards\n\nTo say Edwards is on the precipice of a superstar leap, his landing at seventh is not meant as disrespect. The FIBA game suits Edwards well, as evidenced by his dominant play during last year's World Cup.\n\nEdwards' scoring is loud, but the other underrated elements of his game is what will pain opponents.\n\n8. Devin Booker\n\nIn 2021, Booker helped lead Team USA to gold as a starter on a team that rang off five straight wins after a stunning loss to open the tournament. He's three years older and an even better player now, and the experience from his first Olympic showing will benefit Booker in 2024.\n\n9. Kawhi Leonard\n\nThis is also the Olympic debut for Leonard, who will head to Paris despite injury woes ending his playoff run early.\n\nLeonard is still an elite two-way talent but a cautious approach could result in a more limited workload for the two-time NBA Finals MVP.\n\n10. Bam Adebayo\n\nIt's important not to understate the importance of the big man in FIBA play. Adebayo led Team USA in rebounding at the Tokyo Olympics and has an opportunity to show just why he's viewed by many as one of the league's more underrated players. Adebayo gets a chance to do a little bit of everything in Paris.\n\n11. Jrue Holiday\n\nHoliday lands at 11 but could very well be the most important player on this roster.\n\nUSA Basketball made it a point to add Holiday, who, as shown during the NBA Finals, is the perfect glue guy to ensure everything goes as it should. His perimeter defense will also stymie opponents.\n\nMORE: Tyrese Haliburton ready to meet gold standard set by USA Basketball at Olympics\n\n12. Tyrese Haliburton\n\nTo be last among the country's greatest players is not a slight but a commentary on how good this Team USA roster is.\n\nHaliburton, who is one of the world's best pure point guards, will be in paradise with the amount of players he can now set up.", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sporting News"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8218690065", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:26:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:26:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:25:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.espn.com.au/nba/story/_/id/40525757/team-usa-basketball-paris-olympics-first-lebron-curry-durant", "title": "'Enjoying every minute': What this Team USA run means for Curry, LeBron and KD", "body": "The first partnership between LeBron James and Stephen Curry in international play began with a phone call in the fall.\n\nThat's when, as Curry recalled, the two longtime NBA rivals spoke about the possibility of teaming up at the 2024 Paris Olympics and joining forces on arguably the greatest collection of talent in basketball history.\n\n\"He was the first person I talked to,\" Curry said Sunday afternoon of his conversation with James. \"'Would this be something I would want to do?' And from there it was like, 'Let's get it.'\"\n\nFor all that Curry, James and fellow future Hall of Famer Kevin Durant have achieved in their careers, they have yet to play together for Team USA. Curry played with Durant during gold-medal runs in the 2010 and 2014 World Championships. James and Durant, meanwhile, won gold at the 2012 London Olympics.\n\nBut this summer, the trio of superstars, now deep into their 30s, will take the floor together in international play for the first time. But don't call it a \"last hurrah.\"\n\n\"Nah,\" Durant told ESPN with a smile, when asked if that was how he viewed finally pairing up with both James and Curry on this team. \"These guys are still playing at an elite level. I feel like Bron could play 4 or 5 more and be here in 2028 in [the Los Angeles Olympics]. Steph's still playing great ball. I'm doing all right, too.\n\n\"I don't want this to be a farewell tour or make it just about us three. It's about trying to win this fifth in a row.\"\n\nHeading into Wednesday's Olympics tune-up against Canada in Las Vegas (10:30 p.m. ET), Team USA is a heavy favorite to win that fifth straight gold medal -- in part because of the presence of the NBA's three biggest American stars. Durant can become the first man to claim four Olympic basketball gold medals, having been part of the past three winning Olympic teams. James, his 40th birthday on the horizon, can add a third gold medal to an already impressive international r\u00e9sum\u00e9.\n\nAnd then there's Curry, who, after 15 seasons in the NBA, is preparing for his Olympic debut.\n\n\"Yeah, it's really cool,\" Curry said. \"I've played with Team USA before on the world championship stage, but I don't know what to expect when it comes to this challenge and this experience. And so I had the first-practice jitters. I'm sure I'll have it for the game [Wednesday] just because I know it means so much. ...\n\n\"Add the surrealness of who is on this team and all the battles that we've had over the course of our careers and the fact that we get to put that energy together as teammates. So I'm enjoying every minute of this.\"\n\nA sense of awe has permeated throughout the first few days of Team USA training camp. Past Olympic rosters have boasted plenty of talent, but there's a reason this group has been compared -- at times favorably -- to the fabled 1992 Dream Team.\n\n\"Do you see this team?\" center Bam Adebayo, playing in his second Olympics after winning gold at the 2020 Tokyo Games, said Sunday. \"When you put [together] a team like this, and you get compared to, like, the Dream Team, it kind of puts it in perspective how great this team can be if we play the right way.\"\n\n\"We got LeBron, KD and Steph,\" Team USA first-timer Anthony Edwards said. \"So I don't feel like nobody can beat those three by themselves on the court.\n\n\"So I mean, you mix in two of us regular guys, we'll be all right.\"\n\nIt has been striking to see Curry and James finally sharing the court for Team USA after their historic playoff battles: four straight NBA Finals showdowns from 2015 to 2018 and again in the 2023 Western Conference semifinals, where James' Los Angeles Lakers knocked out Curry and the defending champion Golden State Warriors.\n\n\"It was like a healthy resentment of somebody that's standing in your way,\" Curry said of his playoff battles against James. \"But through it all, there's obviously the utmost respect for who he is as a person and player and like how good he is and the challenge of trying to beat him and trying to solve that problem every year.\"\n\nAdded James: \"I know how much he loves to win and how much he loves to be in competition. We've always had like these short moments like either All-Star Games or whatever the case may be, where we had these short pockets of time together and it's been super organic and easy.\"\n\nCurry, James and Durant have spent much of the past two decades fighting against one another for NBA supremacy. For the next six weeks, they'll play side by side and try to enjoy the process of the trio's first -- and possibly only -- Olympic run together on the international stage.\n\n\"I can't speak for those two guys, but for me it's going to be ecstatic excitement, a humbling wow factor,\" James told ESPN. \"The last 15, 17, 18 years, myself, Steph, KD, have been the talk of the NBA. ...\n\n\"We don't know how many more opportunities we're going to have to even play the game. So to be able to have this moment at this point in our careers is just super special.\"", "source": {"uri": "espn.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-415658610", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "02:22:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T02:22:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T01:43:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/olympics-news-joel-embiid-drops-blunt-nikola-jokic-take-ahead-of-paris", "title": "Joel Embiid drops blunt Nikola Jokic take ahead of Paris Olympics", "body": "Joel Embiid gets real about his true focus amid looming Serbia matchup.\n\nJoel Embiid and Team USA are on a mission to bring home the gold from the upcoming 2024 Paris Olympics. The Americans have won the gold in the men's basketball tournament in the Summer Olympics since 2008 and they are unsurprisingly the favorite to win their fifth gold in a row.\n\nAll that being said, winning the Olympics isn't the lock that it used to be for Team USA. The rest of the world has significantly diminished the gap between themselves and the Americans, who will be sending a loaded roster filled with future Hall of Famers to Europe to try and prove to the world once again that when it comes to the sport of basketball, there is not a nation out there better than the United States.\n\nTeam USA will be put to an acid test early in the Paris tournament, with Nikola Jokic and Serbia meeting them for both teams' first games in the 2024 Olympics. Asked about his looming matchup against NBA rival, the Philadelphia 76ers star big man said that it's never his focus.\n\n\"I don't care about Joki\u0107. I'm playing for my national team,\" Joel Embiid said (h/t Justin Russo).\n\n\"It's all about focusing on ourselves and trying to make sure everybody's on the same page. When we get there, we've got to know what we got to focus on. Right now it's just about finding ways to get better every single day,\" added Embiid, who holds French and American citizenship.\n\nJokic and Serbia are among the countries expected to be the biggest obstacles for Embiid and Team USA.\n\nIt can be recalled that during the group phase of the 2016 Rio Olympics, Jokic scored 25 points on 11/15 shooting from the floor with six rebounds and three assists in a close 96-93 loss to the United States. The two teams met again in the gold medal match where the Americans flexed their muscles and crushed Serbia to the tune of a 96-66 score. Jokic scored just six points on 3/5 shooting in that contest.\n\nIn that edition of the Olympics, Team USA had a frontcourt featuring DeMarcus Cousins and DeAndre Jordan. This time around, it's going to be Embiid, Anthony Davis of the Los Angeles Lakers, and Bam Adebayo of the Miami Heat.\n\nJoel Embiid debuts for Team USA\n\nEmbiid will be getting his first taste of Olympic basketball and he'll be doing it with the No. 1 ranked team in the world. Since he also has a French passport, many initially believed that he'd choose to represent France in the Olympics. A frontcourt that parades Rudy Gobert, Victor Wembanyama, and Embiid would have posed a huge threat to the rest of the competition in Paris. However, Embiid elected to play for the United States.\n\nAfter an early first-round exit from the 2024 NBA Playoffs with the 76ers, Embiid could brighten up his summer with a gold in Paris.\n\nIn the 2023-24 NBA season, Embiid averaged 34.7 points, 11.0 rebounds, and 5.6 assists while shooting 52.9 percent from the field.\n\nTeam USA 2024 Paris Olympics schedule\n\nThe Americans will open their Paris campaign against Serbia on July 28. Then they will go up against South Sudan on July 31 before finishing up their group play schedule with a showdown versus Puerto Rico on August 3. The quarterfinals are scheduled on August 6, the semifinals on August 8, and the gold medal game on August 10.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ClutchPoints"}, {"uri": "8215639391", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "17:00:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T17:00:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T17:00:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.totalprosports.com/nba/joel-embiid-opens-up-about-representing-team-usa-and-chasing-olympic-dreams/", "title": "Joel Embiid Opens Up About Representing Team USA and Chasing Olympic Dreams", "body": "Philadelphia 76ers star Joel Embiid is ready to live out a long-held dream. The newly minted American citizen recently expressed his excitement about representing Team USA at the upcoming Paris 2024 Olympics.\n\nThe French national team was an option for Embiid, who is a dual US and Cameroon citizen. However, ultimately, he chose to join Team USA. Even Embiid expects to hear a lot of boos from French fans but remains confident in his choice. He has already begun training with Team USA, which shows that he is ready and willing to do what it takes.\n\nThe power forward of the Philadelphia 76ers isn't worried about French fans booing him during the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris. Rather, he's thrilled about the opportunity and ready to soak up the knowledge that comes with performing alongside world-class players. In a recent video, he said,\" It means so much. It's been a dream for a long time. It's an electric group of guys, especially with such great players and the type of talent that you have. It's fun to be a part of.\"\n\nHe said about the team's environment, \"I'm just enjoying it. I play against them, so I feel like I know a lot about them, but I'm just being around them and learning how to play with each other.\"\n\nPicking a team for the Olympics was tough for the 30-year-old NBA star. Due to his dual citizenship, Embiid had the option to play for France, but he ultimately felt a deep connection with the USA. Embiid has been living in America for a long time, and his son was also born there.\n\nLast October, the 30-year-old posted about his decision on social media. He noted, \"I'm really proud and excited about this decision. It was not easy. I am blessed to call Cameroon, France, and the USA home.\"\n\nHe further added, \"After talking to my family, I knew it had to be Team USA. I want to play with my brothers in the league. I want to play for my fans because they've been incredible since the day I came here. Most of all, I want to honor my son, who was born in the US. I want my boy to know I played my first Olympics for him.\"\n\nWith him, the Team USA got a star-studded line-up including LeBron James, Kevin Durant, and the sharpshooting Steph Curry. {"uri": "2024-07-417816035", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:45:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:45:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:31:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/olympics-news-joel-embiid-sends-warning-to-anybody-who-tries-to-bully-team-usa", "title": "Joel Embiid Sends Warning To Anybody Who Tries To 'Bully' Team USA", "body": "Team USA adds Joel Embiid, Bam Adebayo, and Anthony Davis to their front court.\n\nWith the Paris Olympics exhibition games starting Wednesday night, Team USA is a much different team than what it was during the FIBA World Cup back in 2023. So much so that there was an apparent \"bully\" problem against Team USA, especially when it came to players down in the paint and the front court, but now it has drastically changed with such players as Philadelphia 76ers star Joel Embiid.\n\nIt would make sense how USA was bullied in their size as they were a small lineup with the starting center being Memphis Grizzlies big man Jaren Jackson Jr. who stands at six foot, 10 inches and is usually a power forward. The coaches on the Olympics team even brought up to the players about the players being \"bullied,\" but the seven foot Embiid believes it will be a different story this time around according to Joe Vardon of The Athletic.\n\n\"Probably everybody knows it's hard to bully me,\" Embiid said. \"And it's hard to bully those other guys.\"\n\nBesides Embiid, more size was added with Los Angeles Lakers star Anthony Davis who is much tougher at playing the center position where he even said that when it comes to the FIBA World Cup team, \"they feel like we got bullied last year.\"\n\nBam Adebayo talks about how Team USA will set the tone\n\nAnother addition to the Paris Olympics team on Team USA is Miami Heat star Bam Adebayo who does stand around six foot, 10 inches, but is one of the best defenders in the league as he was a finalist last season for the Defensive Player of the League. He was also on NBA's All-Defense first team and won the gold medal with USA in 2021 as with all the intensity added to Team USA, he believes they \"will definitely set the tone early.\"\n\n\"I feel like we will definitely set the tone early, no matter who is in the game,\" Adebayo said. \"I feel like the tone will be set from the start to the finish.\"\n\nSomeone that Adebayo knows very well that is on the coaching staff for USA is Heat head coach Erik Spoelstra who talked about the areas of need that were addressed whether it be size or physicality. He would even say that on this current iteration, the squad this year has \"Hall of Fame rebounders\" on the roster in Embiid, Davis, and Adebayo.\n\n\"We feel like size, physicality, rebounding ability -- we feel like we've addressed that,\" Spoelstra said, who is an assistant under Team USA's head coach Steve Kerr. \"These are Hall of Fame rebounders that we have on this roster.\"\n\nTeam USA coach speaks on how basketball is played internationally\n\nAnother coach who was on Kerr's USA staff along with Spoelstra was Los Angeles Clippers head coach Tyronn Lue and also talked about how they weren't prepared for the size in the last go around. He would emphasize how internationally, the game is much different compared to the NBA via The Athletic.\n\n\"Over there (internationally) the game is different,\" Lue said. \"Here (in the NBA), you can't really touch guys, can't be physical. Over there (Team USA) found out that they can be physical, they can run guys over, use your hands. It was just a different game, and we weren't prepared for it. And (so) we talked about it (Friday night).\"\n\nAdebayo hypes up Team USA heading into Paris Olympics\n\nSize and physicality will especially be crucial when facing teams like France with Victor Wembanyama and Rudy Gobert or even against Serbia who has superstar Nikola Jokic. Still, the current Team USA has an immense amount of hype, but the players realize that, especially Adebayo who said that people have compared them to the \"Dream Team\" who had such players as Michael Jordan, Larry Bird, Magic Johnson, and many more legends.\n\n\"Do you see this team?\" Adebayo said. \"I don't disrespect any other country at all, so. So don't let that be your headline. But, you know, you put a team together like this and you get compared to the Dream Team, it kind of puts it in perspective of how great this team can be. You put a team like this together, and we play the right way, it's going to be hard to beat us.\"\n\nUSA's first exhibition game will be against a formidable rival in Team Canada who beat them in the FIBA World Cup to get the bronze medal as they have Oklahoma City Thunder's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Houston Rockets' Dillon Brooks. The latter would send a warning to Team USA despite their bolstered lineup meaning that despite the game being an exhibition, it should be an intense one that starts at 10:30 p.m. (EST).", "source": {"uri": "8219278002", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:24:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:24:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:23:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/basketball-network-nba/we-want-the-gold-dillon-brooks-has-his-eyes-set-on-toppling-team-usa-in/article_abcf47bd-a696-598d-bb79-b995b4da3495.html", "title": "\"We want the gold\" - Dillon Brooks has his eyes set on toppling Team USA in the Paris Olympics", "body": "Houston Rockets guard Dillon Brooks has never lacked confidence. In fact, his confidence, which borders on cockiness, has been a defining characteristic of his basketball career. But now, the Canadian-born player has set his sights on an even bigger goal - winning gold at the Paris Olympics.\n\nCanada, the underdog in this scenario, must eventually overcome a Team USA squad that features some of the NBA's greatest players: LeBron James, Steph Curry, and Kevin Durant. However, despite the daunting task, Brooks and his team still believe they have what it takes to topple Team USA and come away with the gold in Paris.\n\nBeat Team USA before\n\nDillon, a renowned defensive pest in the NBA, has every reason to believe they can beat the American team. After all, it wasn't too long ago that they did just that in the 2023 FIBA World Cup in Manila, Philippines. This victory, even though Team USA didn't bring their big guns, was a significant achievement for Canada. Their 127-118 overtime victory secured them the bronze medal and denied the Americans a podium finish.\n\nMaking that victory sweeter for Brooks was that he unloaded a whopping 39 points on Team USA's defense in that game. These things, along with the presence of proven superstars like Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Jamal Murray on Canada's roster, fuel Dillon's belief that they can defeat this formidable American squad.\n\n\"The belief was always there; we just had to put it together. Now we've got a lot of players that are committed, willing to build this every single summer to get better and better and build chemistry and build camaraderie,\" the 2023 All-Defense team member told The Athletic.\n\nAlthough Canada's roster looks nothing like Team USA's All-Star-laden roster, it still features several NBA standouts, such as RJ Barrett, Lu Dort, Trey Lyles, Andrew Nembhard, and Kelly Olynyk. In the knockout format the Olympics use in the tournament's latter stages, Brooks believes Canada is capable of winning gold.\n\n\"Our time was last year. And now (it's) our time for this year. But instead of getting bronze, we want the gold,\" the 6-foot-6 wingman boldly asserted.\n\nRelated: Kobe Bryant's former bodyguard compared working for him and other NBA stars: \"Kobe was a sit outside-the-gate person\"\n\nFirst shot at Team USA\n\nBrooks and the rest of his Canadian team get their first shot at Team USA on Wednesday when they square off in an exhibition game. The former Oregon Duck sees this game as an opportunity to show the world what they can do, and what better way to do it than at the Americans' expense.\n\n\"I take it as another game, but me being who I am, I like to make a statement,\" Dillon uttered. \"So I'll be ready to play. Team Canada will be ready to play, and we're gonna go balls to the wall and watch the film after and see if we got better.\"\n\nWith the Olympics only a few weeks away, this game should benefit both teams, allowing them to work out any kinks and fine-tune their strategies and rotations. For Canada, this game would give them an opportunity to see where they stack up against the team that is the odds-on favorite to win the Olympic gold medal.\n\nIn addition to Bron, Steph, and KD, Team USA also has 2023 NBA MVP Joel Embiid, Anthony Davis, Jrue Holiday, Jayson Tatum, Bam Adebayo, Devin Booker, Kawhi Leonard, Anthony Edwards, and Tyrese Haliburton.\n\nBrooks said he's glad Team USA is bringing its best players, as it would give his team a fair grasp of where they stand against the world's best at this point.\n\n\"You know, I'm happy that they're playing because, you know, we get to test our talents against theirs. And you know, it should be a fun one,\" Brooks shared.\n\nGiven Dillon's history with the likes of LeBron and Steph, this exhibition game should be nothing short of exciting for fans and players
