{"uri": "8217875172", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "02:14:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T02:14:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T02:14:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.abc6.com/tammi-reiss-fulfills-lifelong-goal-with-usas-olympic-three-on-three-womens-basketball-team/", "title": "Tammi Reiss Fulfills Lifelong Goal with USA's Olympic Three-on-Three Women's Basketball Team | ABC6", "body": "With two 3\u00d73 teams automatically qualified for the 2024 Olympic Games, USA Basketball announced today that Joe Lewandowski will coach the 2024 3\u00d73 USA Men's National Team and Jennifer Rizzotti, president of the Connecticut Sun, will coach the 2024 3\u00d73 USA Women's National Team in Paris. Rhode Island women's basketball head coach Tammi Reiss was named Assistant Coach under Rizzotti.\n\n\"Two accomplished coaches will lead our 3\u00d73 efforts in Paris,\" said Jim Tooley, USA Basketball CEO. \"We are grateful to Jen and Joe for their ongoing commitments to USA Basketball and proud to have the opportunity for both 3\u00d73 teams to compete at the Olympic Games.\"\n\nRizzotti, a longtime member of the USA Basketball family, will be at the helm for the defending Olympic gold medalist women. Last year, Rizzotti coached three gold-medal-winning teams, including the 2023 USA 3\u00d73 Women's World Cup Team, 2023 USA 3\u00d73 Women's AmeriCup Team and 2023 USA 3\u00d73 Women's Pan American Team. She made her 3\u00d73 coaching debut in 2022 on the FIBA 3\u00d73 Women's Series.\n\nRizzotti, who has USA Basketball 5-on-5 and 3\u00d73 coaching experience, won gold as an assistant coach to Dawn Staley at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. She currently chairs the USA Basketball Women's National Team Committee (5-on-5), which will select the 2024 USA Women's National Team.\n\n\"I am absolutely honored to be continuing my USA Basketball journey as the head coach of the 2024 USA 3\u00d73 Women's National Team,\" Rizzotti said. \"It has been the joy of my career to coach athletes who are representing our country on the biggest stage at the Olympic Games. This sport is exhilarating to watch, challenging to coach and extremely rewarding to be a part of. I am grateful for all the people who were instrumental in helping us qualify for Paris and I look forward to preparing the athletes for one of those most competitive environments I will ever be a part of.\"\n\nJoining Rizzotti as assistant coach is Tammi Reiss (University of Rhode Island). An assistant under Rizzotti at the FIBA 3\u00d73 World Cup, Reiss has additional 3\u00d73 coaching experience as the head coach for the 2023 USA U24 Team on the FIBA Women's Series and at the 2023 USA 3\u00d73 Nations League Final.\n\n\"Tammi is the perfect complement to me,\" Rizzotti said. \"I am thrilled to have her by my side. She is passionate, detail oriented, focused and fun to be around. She is also one of the few coaches who understands 3\u00d73 like I do and I know she will work tirelessly to make sure that we are ready for the competition.\"\n\nLewandowski, who has been coaching and advising the USA Basketball 3\u00d73 program since 2014, will lead a team of men making their 3\u00d73 Olympic debuts. With over a dozen USA Basketball coaching assignments, Lewandowski most recently led the 2023 USA 3\u00d73 Men's Pan American Team to the gold medal and the 2023 USA 3\u00d73 Men's World Cup Team to silver.\n\nLewandowski has been a coaching fixture at nearly every level and is currently the head coach at Butler County Community College in Oak Hills, Pennsylvania. A standout player, Lewandowski's collegiate career began at Butler County, where he was named a National Junior College Athletic Association All-American before transferring to Slippery Rock University.\n\n\"There is no greater honor than representing your country and wearing USA across your chest at the Olympic Games,\" Lewandowski said. \"This is incredibly humbling. I am beyond blessed and thankful for the opportunity to represent USA Basketball in Paris this summer.\"\n\nAdditionally, James Fraschilla (Capital City Go-Go) will serve as assistant coach for the men's squad. Fraschilla previously assisted USA Basketball's Team Washington DC and Team Omaha on the 2023 FIBA 3\u00d73 Men's World Tour.\n\n\"It is very exciting to work with James as we prepare our athletes for Paris,\" Lewandowski said. \"He is a tireless worker on the journey to pursue USA Basketball's first 3\u00d73 men's Olympic gold medal. We are looking forward to the challenge.\"\n\nFIBA previously announced that USA Basketball automatically qualified men's and women's 3\u00d73 teams for the 2024 Olympics. In each category, the United States was one of three countries that qualified based on FIBA 3\u00d73 world rankings as of Oct. 31, 2023, and will bypass the 2024 Olympic Qualifying Tournaments. For more information about Olympic qualification, click here.\n\nThe 2024 Paris Olympics are set for July 26-Aug. 11, with the 3\u00d73 basketball competition set for July 30-Aug.5 at Place de la Concorde. More information, including 2024 USA 3\u00d73 National Team training camp details and complete competition schedule, will be announced at a later date.\n\nDifferent than 5-on-5, 3\u00d73 is played on a half-court with a 10-minute game clock and 12-second shot clock. Play is continuous, as teams \"clear\" the ball behind the 2-point line following a made basket, defensive rebound or steal. The first team to score 21 points via 1-point field goals or 2-pointers behind the arc is victorious; or if time expires then the team leading wins.", "source": {"uri": "abc6.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8217469393", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:31:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:31:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:30:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.foxla.com/sports/olympics-2024-team-usa-basketball-california", "title": "Olympics 2024: Meet the athletes with California ties on Team USA Basketball", "body": "LOS ANGELES - The Men's and Women's USA basketball teams for the 2024 Paris Olympics are fully loaded with All-Star talent. The athletes hail from coast to coast, and from San Diego to the Bay Area and beyond, many of them have ties to the Golden State - whether they grew up here or currently play for a California team.\n\nOf course, California is an athletic powerhouse and some of the best athletes in every sport have California here. But here, we're going to focus on hoops.\n\nThe 12-member men's team players were selected by the USA Men's Basketball Team managing director, Grant Hill. As one of the most respected names in the sport, Hill is an Olympic gold medalist and spent 19 years playing in the NBA. The 2024 roster is bursting at the seams with skill, technique and athleticism, showcasing a combination of battle-tested veterans and the young and hungry future faces of the league.\n\nBelow is the full roster for the 2024 USA Basketball Men's 5 x 5 Olympic Team:\n\nIn addition, the men's national basketball team coaching staff is equally impressive as the roster. Two of the coaches for Team USA also have California ties. Golden State Warriors head coach Steve Kerr serves as the head coach of the program and LA Clippers head coach Tyronn Lue is one of the assistant coaches, along with Erik Spoelstra (Miami Heat) and Mark Few (Gonzaga University).\n\nCalifornia connection:\n\nStephen Curry has roots all across the U.S. He was born in Akron, Ohio, like fellow NBA legend, LeBron James. He grew up in North Carolina, where he elevated his game at Davidson College. After three seasons, he was selected by the Golden State Warriors as the seventh overall pick in the 2009 NBA Draft. Since then, as one of the faces of the league, he has fully embraced life in the Bay Area on and off the court. Curry is a four-time NBA champion and ten-time NBA All-Star.\n\nCalifornia connection:\n\nNBA superstar Anthony Davis has been playing for the Los Angeles Lakers since 2019. He's one-half of one of the best duos in the league with LeBron James. The Chicago native attended the University of Kentucky and was then selected first overall in the 2012 NBA Draft by the New Orleans Pelicans where he quickly became one of the best big men in the game. The nine-time All-Star, who won All-Star MVP in 2017, has previously won two other gold medals - the 2014 FIBA World Cup and the 2012 Olympic Games. Davis is also the eighth player in history to have won an NBA title, an NCAA championship, and an Olympic gold medal.\n\nCalifornia ties:\n\nJrue Holiday is coming to Paris after winning his second NBA championship. He won his first NBA title in 2021 with the Milwaukee Bucks and earned his second with the Boston Celtics last month. He is one of the three Holiday brothers, and his siblings Justin and Aaron also play in the NBA. The Holidays were born and raised in Southern California and attended Campbell Hall in Studio City. Jrue Holiday went to UCLA for a year before he was declared for the NBA Draft. In 2009, he was selected 17th overall by the Philadelphia 76ers.\n\nCalifornia connection:\n\nAs the oldest active player in the NBA and on the Olympic roster, LeBron James continues to be a force on the court. James, along with Kevin Durant, will suit up for Team USA for the fourth time.\n\nWhile his roots are in Ohio, the NBA legend has been a Los Angeles Laker since 2019 and recently, he signed a two-year deal. Next season, he will begin his 22nd season in the league and has an extensive list of accolades to show for it. The four-time NBA champion and 20-time NBA All-Star won his first gold medal in 2001 at the USA Basketball Youth Development Festival. He won three others at the 2007 FIBA Americas Championship, as well as the 2008 and 2012 Olympic Games. As his time in the league nears its end, this will be his final Olympic run.\n\nCalifornia ties:\n\nKawhi Leonard is a two-time NBA Finals MVP who plays for the Los Angeles Clippers. He was born in Los Angeles before he moved to the Inland Empire. As a teenager, he became a standout at Martin Luther King High School in Moreno Valley. Leonard played for two seasons at San Diego State University before declaring for the 2011 NBA Draft, in which he was selected as the 15th overall pick. He won championships with the San Antonio Spurs and the Toronto Raptors and has since brought his talents back to his hometown.\n\nCalifornia ties:\n\nKareem Maddox's Olympic profile describes him as \"one of the most decorated American athletes in the discipline\" in reference to the 3x3 game. While he may not be as commonly known as his fellow Team USA athletes, his resume proves he shines in the worldwide stage. He was born in Los Angeles and attended Oak Park High School and attended Princeton University for four seasons. He won gold medals at the 2023 Pan American Games, 2022 FIBA AmeriaCup, the 2021 FIBA AmeriCup, the 2019 Pan American Games and the 2019 FIBA World Cup - all on 3x3 teams.\n\nThe WNBA is exploding in popularity. The USA women's basketball team athletes were selected by the USA Women's National Team Committee and approved by the USA Basketball Board of Directors.\n\nFans will be able to see the star-studded Olympic team take on the WNBA All-Stars during the 2024 WNBA All-Star Game in Phoenix on Saturday, July 20.\n\nChelsea Gray was born in Manteca, a mid-sized city located between Stockton and Modesto. Data from Team USA indicates she is 25-3 in a USA Basketball uniform and she has previously won gold medals at the 2020 Olympics and the 2022 FIBA World Cup. Gray has won three WNBA championships - two with her current team, the Las Vegas Aces, in which she won WNBA Finals MVP in 2022, and her first with the LA Sparks in 2016. Before going pro, she played four seasons at Duke University where she became the first player in the program to record two triple-doubles.\n\nCalifornia ties:\n\nKelsey Plum is another player for the Las Vegas Aces with California roots. Plum was born in Poway and attended La Jolla Country Day before she spent her college year at the University of Washington. She was the first overall pick in the 2017 WNBA Draft and was selected by the San Antonio Stars before they relocated to Sin City. It's no surprise she has four gold medals under her belt - the 2013 FIBA U19 World Cup, the 2019 FIBA World Cup, the 2020 Olympic Games 3x3, and the 2022 FIBA World Cup.\n\nCalifornia ties:\n\nSabrina Ionescu is one of the most recognizable faces in the game. You've probably seen her highlights on social media or seen her face in a commercial, and the 26-year-old's game is worth the hype. She was born in Walnut Creek and attended Miramonte High School in Orinda (Contra Costa County). Her popularity exploded during her four seasons at Oregon and in 2020, she was the first overall pick in the WNBA Draft. Like several of her Olympic teammates, her accolades include numerous gold medals, which she earned at the 2022 FIBA World Cup, the 2019 Pan American Games (3x3), the 2014 FIBA U17 World Cup, and the 2013 FIBA Americas U16 Championship.\n\nCalifornia ties:\n\nIf there was a Mt. Rushmore of the WNBA, Diana Taurasi would certainly be on it. Taurasi was born and raised in Chino and attended Don Antonio Lugo High School. She began gaining national attention while at the University of Connecticut, where she won three consecutive NCAA championships. At 42 years old, the 3-time WNBA champion isn't slowing down anytime soon. The Phoenix Mercury superstar is no stranger to the Olympic Games and holds the record for most Olympic titles in US basketball history - having won gold medals at Athens 2004, Beijing 2008, London 2012, Rio 2016, and Tokyo 2020.\n\nCalifornia connection:\n\nDearica Hamby is having a stellar season with the LA Sparks. She was selected to the 3x3 team in late June after her teammate, Cameron Brink, suffered an injury earlier this season. The spot is rightfully hers as she's been a dominant force on the court. She previously won a gold medal at the 2023 FIBA 3x3 AmeriCup. She was also on the 2023 USA Women's National Team and the 2022 USA Women's World Cup Qualifying Team.\n\nYou can get a first look at the 5x5 teams very soon. The men's team plays an exhibition game against Team Canada on Wednesday, July 10 in Las Vegas. Meanwhile, the women's team will take on the WNBA All-Stars at the 2024 WNBA All-Star Game in Phoenix on Saturday, July 20.", "source": {"uri": "foxla.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX 11 Los {"uri": "8218074545", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "05:44:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T05:44:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T05:43:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://www.nbcsports.com/nba/news/who-should-start-for-team-usa-lebron-or-curry-off-the-bench", "title": "Who should start for Team USA? LeBron or Curry off the bench?", "body": "LAS VEGAS -- Don't read too much into who is starting for Team USA when it takes the court Wednesday night against Canada.\n\n\"We are purposely going to just throw all kinds of different combinations out there...\" USA head coach Steve Kerr said. \"I imagine I'll change the starting lineup for the first few games, just try different ones. Everybody understands this is a very unique situation. They're all not only starters, but superstars, future Hall of Famers. So they all deserve to start but only five can. We will figure it out.\"\n\nKerr has options, but if we don't see the Paris starting five against Canada -- and we definitely won't with Kevin Durant out -- then who will start in Paris? Let's break it down.\n\nSteve Kerr learned a hard lesson at the World Championships in the Philippines last summer -- his small-ball lineups don't work the same way in the physical game allowed internationally as they do in the NBA. The USA struggled to match up with size.\n\nEnter Joel Embiid -- the most dominant physical big man in the NBA (or, at least tied with Nikola Jokic). If Team USA takes home another gold it will be because Embiid -- along with some help off the bench from Anthony Davis and Bam Adebayo (who Kerr seemed to use together in scrimmages, bumping Bam to the four) -- could match up physically inside with anyone. Kerr added this style of play may be an adjustment for Embiid because he'll be down on the block more.\n\n\"Nothing changes,\" Embiid responded. \"I'll still be dominant as I always am. I'll just see a few more touches in the low post and go from there.\"\n\nThere is a political element to being USA basketball coach and with this team in particular -- Kerr has to start these three legends. Even on a team of superstars, these three icons can't come off the bench.\n\nThis is also not a bad thing. The plan in scrimmages appears to have been LeBron as a point-forward initiating the offense, with his elite decision-making and passing setting everyone up, then have Curry working more off the ball and as the secondary shot-creator. (Still, the USA Select team was quick to double Curry once he got the ball and started making a move.) Durant will fit into that nicely once he returns from his calf soreness.\n\nHowever, don't be shocked if Kerr ultimately asks one of these guys to be the sixth man as he works through his thought process because some other lineup combo just works better. It would be weird to see Curry or LeBron coming off the bench, but it's not out of the question.\n\nThis final spot could go a lot of directions, but whoever it is has to take on the 2008 Olympics Kobe Bryant's \"just tell me who to stop\" defensive mindset.\n\nI'll take Leonard. He's still one of the best on-ball defenders in the league, physical (which will play well in FIBA ball), long, and just knows how to play the game. Tell him to just shut someone down, and they'll be toast.\n\n\"It's fun coaching Kawhi, just seeing him up close,\" Kerr said. \"Just the physicality, the strength, the skill. And it's great to see him back on the court.\"\n\nIf not Leonard, Kerr could go a number of directions here: Jayson Tatum or Anthony Edwards can step into this role, or if the USA needs to go bigger against an opponent Anthony Davis can start. If Kerr wants to go smaller, there is Jrue Holiday or maybe Devin Booker.\n\nAll that versatility gets to the key point with Team USA: What matters is not who starts games but who finishes close ones. Kerr will have options when that happens, he can play through his roster in these games and then ride a hot hand at the end -- maybe it's\n\nBooker's night or Holiday's night or Tyrese Haliburton's night. For someone to even catch the Clippers star with a smile on his face is a rare occurrence.\n\nHowever, it looks like he enjoys being around other stars, which is allowing him to open up and show a different side that those covering the NBA are not familiar with. {"uri": "8218804024", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:36:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:36:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:35:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "http://mynewsla.com/orange-county/2024/07/10/us-mens-olympic-basketball-team-to-face-canada-in-exhibition-opener/", "title": "US Men's Olympic Basketball Team To Face Canada in Exhibition Opener - MyNewsLA.com", "body": "The 2024 U.S. Olympic men's basketball team will begin exhibition play against Canada in Las Vegas Wednesday evening with a roster including LeBron James, his Lakers teammate Anthony Davis and Clippers forward Kawhi Leonard.\n\nThe 39-year-old James will become the oldest player in U.S. men's national team history when he takes the court, breaking the previous record set by Hall of Famer Reggie Miller, who was 37 when he played in the 2002 FIBA World Cup.\n\nThis is the fourth Olympic selection for James, a member of the U.S. gold medal-winning 2008 and 2012 teams and the 2004 team that won the bronze medal.\n\nDavis was also a member of the 2012 team.\n\nLeonard is among the five first-time Olympians on the team, along with Golden State Warriors guard Stephen Curry, Minnesota Timberwolves guard Anthony Edwards, Philadelphia 76ers center Joel Embiid and Indiana Pacers guard Tyrese Haliburton.\n\nThere is a fourth player on the team with a Los Angeles tie, Boston Celtics guard Jrue Holiday, a former standout at UCLA and Campbell Hall School in Studio City.\n\nHoliday is among five members of the gold medal-winning team from the Tokyo Olympics seeking a second consecutive gold medal, along with Celtics teammate Jayson Tatum, Miami Heat center Bam Adebayo, Phoenix Suns guard Devin Booker and Phoenix forward Kevin Durant, also a member of the 2012 and 2016 gold medal-winning teams.\n\nDurant will miss Wednesday's game because of a left calf strain.\n\nThe team has six players who have won a combined 15 NBA championships, the most combined championships and NBA champions entering an Olympic tournament in USA Basketball history.\n\nAll 12 players on the roster have been NBA all-stars and combined to have 84 All-Star Game appearances. No other team in USA Basketball history has combined to have over 70 combined all-star appearances.\n\nThe U.S. is coached by Warriors coach Steve Kerr, an alum of what is now known as Palisades Charter High School. Clippers coach Tyronn Lue is among the assistant coaches, along with Gonzaga coach Mark Few and Heat coach Erik Spoelstra.\n\nCanada's 15-player roster includes 10 NBA players, among them Houston Rockets forward Dillon Brooks, best remembered by Lakers fans for calling James old following Game 2 of a 2023 first-round playoff series when he played for the Memphis Grizzlies, and for getting ejected in Game 3 after receiving a flagrant foul for hitting James in the groin.\n\nThe team is coached by Brooklyn Nets coach Jordi Fern\u00c3\u00a1ndez.\n\nThe U.S. tops the rankings under FIBA, basketball's international governing body and based on results in official FIBA competitions and their qualifiers over an eight-year-period. Canada is ranked seventh.\n\nThe 7:30 p.m. game at T-Mobile Arena will be televised by FS1.\n\nThe exhibition is the first of five for the U.S., which will next play Australia Monday at 9 a.m. Pacific Daylight Time in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.\n\nThe Americans will begin Olympic play July 28 against Serbia in Lille, France, where group play will be held. The knockout and medal rounds of the 5\u00d75 Olympic tournament will be played in Paris.\n\nThe U.S. has won four consecutive Olympic gold medals in 5\u00d75 men's basketball and seven of the eight Damn near feels surreal,\" one fan said.\n\n\"This team is stacked can't wait to see them drop teams off,\" another fan said.\n\n\"Annoyed at how excited i am to watch this team,\" a third fan posted.\n\n\"They have to win the gold - and I think they will,\" a fourth fan commented.\n\n\"So many legends - should be a great watch,\" a fifth fan said.\n\nAt recent Games, a number of stars tend to sit out the action.\n\nThis roster for Paris is perhaps the best since the \"Redeem Team\" at the 2008 Olympics in Beijng, China.\n\nThe United States will be particularly determined to land gold in the basketball competition in Paris.\n\nThe US only finished in fourth place at last year's World Cup.\n\nGermany beat Serbia in the final, while Canada beat the US to claim third place.\n\n\"Obviously, last year we didn't do what we wanted to do,\" Tyrese Haliburton said.\n\n\"And that was frustrating because any time you get to represent USA Basketball, the expectation is to win. And we weren't able to do that.\"\n\nLeBron, 39, is playing in his first Olympics since the 2012 Games in London.\n\nThe 39-year-old will arrive at the Games having signed a new deal with the Los {"uri": "8216174167", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "03:20:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T03:20:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T03:19:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://www.arcamax.com/sports/olympics/s-3321323", "title": "Adam Hill: Dad, White and Blue: Joel Embiid's son fuels Team USA decision", "body": "LAS VEGAS -- Joel Embiid is done answering questions about why he decided to play for Team USA in his first Olympics this year.\n\nYes, he could've played for his native Cameroon or France, where he was granted citizenship in 2022. But his only focus is winning a gold medal after donning the red, white and blue during Team USA practices at UNLV this week.\n\n\"I've known these guys for a long time, so it made it easy to be a part of this special team and this country, which I love and where I'm raising my family and my American son,\" Embiid said Monday. \"It's fun to be around so many great players, but everything is serious. We have a goal to accomplish, so it's all about maximizing the amount of time we have together to get on the same page and try to get better every day.\"\n\nThe decision\n\nEmbiid, 30, declined to say why he picked the United States in October, saying he has addressed the topic already.\n\nHe was previously linked to the Cameroon national team, but he did not play a game for the country during the 2017 FIBA AfroBasket tournament. Cameroon ultimately didn't qualify for the 2024 Olympics in men's basketball after losing to Latvia on Saturday.\n\nFrance was also an option after Embiid was granted French citizenship despite never having lived in the country. He became a U.S. citizen in 2022 as well. There was some thought he would join French standouts Rudy Gobert and Victor Wembanyama and challenge Team USA's Olympic dominance.\n\nEmbiid's decision became clear in October. He ultimately wanted to compete for the country where his son Arthur was born.\n\nEmbiid arrived in the U.S. when he was 15 years old and has stayed since. He played at Kansas for a year and has starred for the Philadelphia 76ers since being drafted third overall in 2014.\n\nHe has often said his son changed everything in his life. {"uri": "8217846262", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "01:37:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T01:37:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T01:36:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://www.nba.com/news/kawhi-leonard-joel-embiid-injuries-olympics", "title": "Kawhi Leonard, Joel Embiid brush aside injury concerns, all-in for Olympics", "body": "LAS VEGAS -- The goal is to reach the Olympic medal platform by strutting, not limping. With that in mind, there's the need to address the twin elephants in the Team USA room: Kawhi Leonard and Joel Embiid.\n\nAs the American men wrapped a four-day camp here Tuesday, the most significant goal was reached -- Embiid and especially Kawhi, who couldn't finish yet another NBA season because of injury, showed no physical issues or concerns.\n\nThis was a matter of high importance, not only for Team USA but obviously the Sixers and Clippers, given the fragility of those two players. In fact, Team USA officials privately expressed concern last month whether Kawhi, specifically, might be an injury scratch altogether or ask for restrictions.\n\nAs for any restrictions: That was non-negotiable for either player, according to those team officials. It was either all-in, or the search for replacement(s) would hastily begin.\n\nThe good news as Team USA prepares for Wednesday's exhibition with Canada is there's no news. Both have been full participants in practices and scrimmages (unlike Kevin Durant, out with a mild calf strain). Neither the players, or their teams, have asked coach Steve Kerr to be placed on a minutes leash.\n\nAnyway, the players themselves badly wanted to be here; this is the first Olympic experience for Kawhi and Embiid, both highly decorated franchise players in search of expanding their own legacies.\n\nEmbiid: \"I've dreamed of this moment, being part of the Olympics, ever since I was a kid, watching it growing up.\"\n\nKawhi: \"I always wanted to be with other talented players, to learn from them, win with them. Been my dream.\"\n\nKawhi was thrilled and honored when chosen for 2024 -- injuries prevented him from previous Team USA selections -- and his 33-year-old body initially cooperated once he accepted the invite last spring. He played 68 games last season, most since 2016-17, and averaged 34 minutes. The Clippers, who wanted to place a heavier emphasis on the regular season compared to years past, were mainly hands-off; he even played back-to-backs.\n\nHowever, two games into the postseason, he was done, plagued by swelling in his repaired right knee. It was the fourth straight postseason he ended by pulling up lame.\n\nSo he has a history, then. And tacking on a month of summer practices and games seemingly would be problematic for someone with that history.\n\nBut Kawhi said, with some caution, he is refreshed and as rejuvenated as he can be:\n\n\"I'm ready to go. Everything's been good so far. I'm playing now so I'm happy. Hopefully it stays that way.\"\n\nHe did admit to a skittish summer process where everything had to go right physically, though, and there was no guarantee of his Team USA presence. He underwent daily treatment (though no surgery) leading up to camp. He responded \"yeah\" when asked if he had initial doubts about playing in the Games following his latest injury.\n\n\"But I took the time,\" he said. \"I was able to turn around over the last two weeks.\"\n\nKawhi seems at peace, to a degree, about his body and the constant struggles with injuries and rehabbing from them.\n\n\"I can't lay out the perfect script for me,\" he said. \"Last year I tried to play as much as possible and felt great, and then after a certain period of time I couldn't go. I don't want to be in the situation where I (find myself) in but I have to take it for what it is.\n\n\"I motivate a lot of people (with injuries) so I got to keep doing what I'm doing. I might be the most known for injuries, so just for me to be able to keep going is going to motivate the next guy. So I'll keep going until I can't. Just going to keep it steady.\"\n\nThere were no ultimatums given by the Clippers regarding his status for Team USA; on the contrary, actually.\n\n\"Everything felt good for him on the lead-up (to USA camp),\" said Ty Lue, an assistant coach on Team USA and also Clippers coach. \"He's moving good right now so I'm just happy that he's feeling pretty good. Hopefully he'll keep moving along and feel 100% when the season starts.\"\n\nEmbiid's injury history isn't as deep but costly and significant as well. Last season he played just 39 games because of knee issues, ruining what shaped up as a historic effort -- he averaged more points (34.7) than minutes played during that stretch yet was ineligible for postseason awards.\n\nIn the playoffs, the former Kia MVP labored, a big man placing pressure on that knee and doing it in the intensity of the postseason. Nonetheless, he was tremendous against the Knicks -- he had a 50-point performance in that first-round series -- while playing 41 minutes a night.\n\nTherefore, like it did with Kawhi, the possibility of bypassing the Olympics in favor of preservation was raised by Embiid -- for about a minute.\n\n\"It came up,\" he said, \"but I never worry about injuries because the moment I do I feel I'm not going to be the same. I think if something happens then it was meant to happen, so I just go with the flow.\n\n\"For me, being part of the Olympics was always the goal. It was an opportunity and a chance I couldn't pass up. And I don't think there is a big risk.\"\n\nThis is important for the American men, because size was a big issue last year during the World Cup; only Bam Adebayo offered much in the middle in terms of proven talent. Embiid said he's out to change that in Paris.\n\n\"As everybody knows it's hard to bully me,\" he said. \"We got enough size. And we got the shooters and talent everywhere. I'll be excited to get the ball in the post, because when I usually play I see double teams every time I touch the ball. So it'll be fun to see single coverage.\"", "source": {"uri": "nba.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBA.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-417658179", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:52:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:52:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:52:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://www.sportsnet.ca/article/canadian-mens-basketball-team-ready-to-test-against-the-best/", "title": "Canadian men's basketball team ready for test against the best", "body": "Michael Grange joins Evanka Osmak to preview the Canada's match against the United States, including their expectations against the world's best, and the x-factor outside of Gilgeous-Alexander and Murray.\n\nLAS VEGAS -- The Canadian men's basketball team is loaded.\n\nCanada is ranked seventh in the world and finished third last year at the FIBA Basketball World Cup, where they recorded wins over teams ranked first (Spain), second (USA) and the defending Olympics silver medalists (France).\n\nThe only team with more NBA players on its final roster at the Olympic tournament in France later this month will be Team USA.\n\nOn Wednesday night in Las Vegas, the scale of the mountain they are trying to climb in their quest for a gold medal will become fully apparent as Canada plays its first exhibition game against the U.S. at T-Mobile Arena.\n\nIt's not the same group that Canada defeated in overtime to win the bronze medal last summer. The only returning players from that team are Tyrese Haliburton and Anthony Edwards. Added for the Olympic tournament are some guys you might have heard of -- LeBron James, Steph Curry, Kevin Durant (though he'll miss the game Wednesday night with a calf strain), Anthony Davis, Jayson Tatum, and Jrue Holiday, just to name a few.\n\nAlso, Joel Embiid will be making his Team USA debut. The 2022-23 NBA MVP was raised in Cameroon, but was made eligible to play for the Americans in time for the Olympics.\n\nSo, yeah. While Canada has added some key reinforcements as well -- Jamal Murray, Andrew Nembhard and likely Trey Lyles -- it's not quite the same, though Murray, Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Nembhard are as a good a guard rotation as any team in the tournament, Team USA included.\n\nBut for all the feel-good moments the Canadians generated with their run at the World Cup last summer, opening their exhibition schedule against the defending Olympic gold medallist brings home the challenge ahead of them.\n\nIt's not the be-all and end-all, given it's just the first exhibition game for each team. Sure it's being shown live in both countries and the arena will be filled, but it doesn't really count.\n\n\"I mean it's a cool experience because of the stage, right?\" said Canadian head coach Jordi Fernandez after his team's practice Tuesday evening. \"And a lot of people are excited to watch the game. But we have a plan to be the team that is pretty physical and runs a lot, and our conditioning is important. As you guys can tell, our guys work really hard. And (Wednesday's) game is just a part of our plan -- I think we have 17 days to get to that day in the best shape (with) our lives connected and ready to fight.\n\n\"... We're gonna try to win every single game, but I'm telling you, I'm not gonna run any of my players to the ground because ... we have a plan and we have to follow it and you know, the emotions ... it would not make sense to play somebody 30 minutes.\"\n\nBut it's still a special moment. In some ways Canada's journey to being a medal favourite in France began this time of year in Las Vegas two summers ago when men's team general manager Rowan Barrett and then-head coach Nick Nurse asked for a core of players to commit to preparing each summer for World Cup qualifying, the World Cup and, eventually, the Olympics.\n\nWhen Gilgeous-Alexander was the first to step up and declare he wanted to be part of it, a new chapter in Canadian basketball began to be written.\n\nA preview of what could easily be a gold-medal final is a great way to start the slow build to what could be a spectacular payoff.\n\nBut then again, it's just an exhibition game.\n\n\"I think no matter who we play, it's gonna be very exciting just because we know the opportunity that's coming up,\" said Gilgeous-Alexander, who had a World Cup All-Star nod sandwiched between consecutive first-team all-NBA honours. \"We all love basketball, and we all love the bright lights, the stage, so I think regardless of who it is, we're going to be very excited, we're going to be jittery. I might dribble it off my foot the first play, but once the ball goes up and down once or twice, it's basketball and we're doing what we love.\"\n\nHow they do it will be crucial. If Canada has a weakness, it's their relative lack of size across their front line. Among Team USA's many strengths is that they have three world-class centres in Embiid, Davis and Bam Adebayo. Any of them pose a problem for Canada, collectively they represent a nightmare.\n\nWe should get a feel for how Canada plans to manage teams that can play with multiple bigs -- France poses a similar challenge with Victor Wembanyama and Rudy Gobert, who are seven-foot-four and seven-foot-two, respectively.\n\n\"It's a good challenge for us,\" said Fernandez. \"We're gonna run a lot. That's how we're gonna handle it. And, you know, we're young, we've trained very well, and we're ready to play. They have one of the best centers in the world (Embiid), well, two of them (Embiid and Anthony Davis) ... they are very, very good players. (We have) a lot of respect for the team and the program. They're No. 1 in the world, and we got to do this work. So one day in the future, we're in that No. 1 spot, so we're excited to play them and face all that adversity with the size.\"\n\nWhile Canada's bigs -- Kelly Olynyk, Dwight Powell and potentially two of Lyles and Khem Birch -- don't necessarily match up with a front line like Team USA can put on the floor, guarding them won't be a one-on-one effort.\n\nCanada's got some excellent defenders among their wing contingent -- Gilgeous-Alexander led the NBA is steals, while Lu Dort, Dillon Brooks, Nembhard and Nickeil Alexander-Walker are all considered strong to elite NBA defenders. They can cause problems with their help, can make it difficult for teams to properly get the ball to their bigs and can speed the game up to take them out of their comfort zone.\n\n\"Be disruptive, (be in) passing lanes, ball pressure, make it tough to enter the ball,\" said Gilgeous-Alexander. \"And then we do have really physical bigs despite them not being seven feet. They're physical, they've played a lot of basketball, they've matched up against all kinds of players. We've also confident in their ability to man-up and guard the basketball down low, too.\"\n\nIt's a tall order against one of the biggest and best teams in international basketball, but that's exactly what this edition of the Canadian men's team signed up for when they committed to their Olympic journey.", "source": {"uri": "sportsnet.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sportsnet"}, "authors": {"uri": "8219178762", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:55:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:55:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:54:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/fadeaway-world-nba/team-usa-bigs-want-to-make-a-statement-at-2024-paris-olympics/article_44178b18-108d-59cc-be6a-66091b73e833.html", "title": "Team USA Bigs Want To Make A Statement At 2024 Paris Olympics", "body": "Team USA's big men are eager to make a statement at the 2024 Paris Olympics, and their comments reveal a determination to address past shortcomings. Last summer's World Cup team struggled with size and physicality, leading to significant losses. Anthony Davis, Bam Adebayo, and Joel Embiid are now poised to change that narrative, as reported by Joe Vardon of The Athletic.\n\nAnthony Davis highlighting the importance of addressing the team's weaknesses said:\n\n\"They feel like we got bullied last year.\"\n\nDavis, with his 7-6 wingspan and recent first-team All-Defense honor, is a crucial addition to bolster the team's interior presence. He emphasized the need to stop the bullying and set a new tone for Team USA. Davis finished the season averaging 24.6 points, 12.6 rebounds, and 2.1 blocks per game.\n\nJoel Embiid, the former MVP, exuding confidence said:\n\n\"Probably everybody knows it's hard to bully me.\"\n\nEmbiid, standing at 7 feet and weighing about 280 pounds, brings immense scoring and defensive abilities. His career-high 34.7 points per game last season for the Philadelphia 76ers, along with 11.0 rebounds and 1.7 blocks, underscores his dominant presence on the court.\n\nBam Adebayo, although the shortest of the trio at 6-9, has proven his mettle as Team USA's starting center during the Tokyo Olympics.\n\n\"I feel like we will definitely set the tone early, no matter who is in the game.\"\n\nAdebayo, coming off a first-team All-Defense season, echoed the sentiment of toughness and resilience. He emphasized the importance of establishing dominance from the start.\n\nThe addition of these three defensive stalwarts aims to counteract the weaknesses exposed in the previous World Cup, where the U.S. was often outmuscled in the paint. Their presence is expected to transform Team USA's approach, focusing on physicality, rebounding, and interior defense.\n\nWith the first exhibition game against Canada approaching, the team is set to demonstrate their newfound strength. The trio of Davis, Embiid, and Adebayo, along with contributions from LeBron James and Kevin Durant, aim to redefine Team USA's identity, making them formidable contenders for the gold medal in Paris.\n\nAs Bam Adebayo aptly put it, \"You put a team like this together, and we play the right way, it's going to be hard to beat us.\"\n\nFrance Is The Only Team Which Can Match Up To Team USA\n\nFrance, with their towering defensive duo of Rudy Gobert and Victor Wembanyama, stands as the only team that can truly challenge Team USA at the 2024 Paris Olympics. Gobert, standing at 7-1, and the 7-5 rookie sensation Wembanyama, have both showcased their defensive prowess by finishing as the winner and runner-up for the NBA Defensive Player of the Year award this season.\n\nThe combination of Gobert and Wembanyama creates a formidable presence in the paint, capable of disrupting even the most potent offenses. Gobert's shot-blocking and rebounding abilities are well-documented, having anchored the Utah Jazz's defense for years and now with the Minnesota Timberwolves.\n\nHis experience and positioning make him a vital piece for France's defensive scheme. On the other hand, Wembanyama's unique blend of height, agility, and shot-blocking instinct adds a new dimension to the French defense. His ability to alter shots and protect the rim makes him a significant threat to any team attempting to score inside.\n\nOne of the critical advantages for France is the absence of the NBA's three-second rule in international play, allowing their big men to camp in the paint and deter any drives to the basket. This rule difference plays perfectly into the hands of France's defensive strategy, making it difficult for opponents to penetrate and score easy baskets.\n\nTeam USA, with its array of superstar talent, including LeBron James, Kevin Durant, and Stephen Curry, will need to be at their absolute best to overcome this defensive juggernaut.\n\nThe presence of Gobert and Wembanyama means that the Americans will have to rely heavily on their perimeter shooting and ball movement to find open shots. Penetrating the French defense will be a significant challenge, and Team USA's guards and wings will need to be precise and efficient in their execution.\n\nThe perimeter players for France, including seasoned veterans and rising stars, are also crucial in supporting their defensive anchors. Players like Evan Fournier and Nicolas Batum bring experience and versatility, capable of both scoring and defending at a high level. Their ability to stretch the floor and create opportunities will be vital for France's overall performance.\n\nFrance's combination of elite defense, anchored by Gobert and Wembanyama, and a solid supporting cast, positions them as the primary challengers to Team USA's quest for Olympic gold. The showdown between these two basketball powerhouses promises to be a thrilling and high-stakes battle on the global stage.\n\nRelated: Kawhi Leonard Withdraws From Team USA For 2024 Paris Olympics\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. If you liked this article, please consider following us on Google News. Short, sweet and to the point,\" said Team USA center Bam Adebayo, summarizing the vice president's message.\n\n\"A great reminder of the fact that we're playing for our country,\" added Team USA coach Steve Kerr, who has met Harris, an Oakland, Calif., native, several times. \"I think the guys really listened to every word. It was great.\"\n\nHarris, in the state of Nevada to make a campaign appearance and speech Tuesday, strode across the court at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas following the Americans' final practice in preparation for Wednesday's exhibition game against Canada -- the first 2024 Olympics tune-up for both countries.\n\nThe entire team, coaching staff and large USA Basketball support staff gathered around the vice president for a short speech, which was out of earshot of reporters, and then posed for pictures.\n\nHarris is a noted Golden State Warriors fan, where Kerr coaches in the NBA and Stephen Curry stars. She was present when the Warriors visited the White House in celebration of their 2022 NBA championship, and on Tuesday posed privately for a picture with Kerr and chatted with Curry after her speech.\n\nHarris' husband, Doug Emhoff, is also a noted NBA fan, though he roots for the Los Angeles Lakers (LeBron James and Anthony Davis of the Lakers are on Team USA this summer).\n\n\"Pretty special moment for the entire group,\" said Erik Spoelstra, an assistant coach with Team USA. \"She just mentioned that we represent our country and everybody is going to be watching and rooting for us. It's a big responsibility.\"\n\nAdebayo, who was on the Olympic team three years ago in Tokyo, when strict protocols were still in place due to COVID-19, said that the group of gold medalists didn't get to meet Harris (or President Joe Biden, for that matter), due to the pandemic.\n\n\"So having her here, being able to speak to us was a dope moment and I'll be able to tell my kids' kids' kids The same goes for Las Vegas Aces No. 22 A'ja Wilson and New York Liberty No. 30 Breanna Stewart.\n\nWhy do USA Basketball players switch up their jersey numbers in red, white and blue? Here's a look back at where the tradition started and what NBA and WNBA stars will sport in Paris.\n\nWhy do USA Basketball teams only use jersey numbers 4-15?\n\nOld international basketball rules restricted players to Nos. 4-15 to make it easier on game officials to communicate with hand signals, per NBC Olympics' Nick Zaccardi.\n\nFIBA dropped the rule in 2014, but USA Basketball still uses Nos. 4-15 for its men's and women's teams to maintain a level of tradition.\n\nDo USA Basketball players wear the same jersey numbers they do in the NBA and WNBA?\n\nNot every USA Basketball player can wear their NBA or WNBA jersey number at the Olympics.\n\nOf course, not every Team USA player wears a jersey number between 4-15 on their professional team. Additionally, multiple members of an Olympic team could wear the same number in the pros.\n\nJust two players on the U.S. men's basketball team for the 2024 Olympics will wear their NBA jersey number in Paris: Anthony Edwards (No. 5) and Bam Adebayo (No. 13). Team USA and Canada now have an understanding of which squads they will need to get through in their respective groups during their quests for gold medals.\n\nIn the meantime, both powerhouses have five exhibition games scheduled so each team can get more comfortable playing together. The first such Showcase game takes place in Las Vegas on Wednesday (10:30 p.m. ET, FS1, Fubo) and pits them against each other -- U.S. vs. Canada -- in the most star-studded friendly match of the summer.\n\nThe teams will then travel to Abu Dhabi and London for more exhibitions, then to Paris for the start of the Olympic games on July 27 and 28. It's a wild stretch of hoops, but both the Americans and Canadians have said they're ready to show up and show out for their respective countries.\n\nLet's dive into the details of Wednesday's exhibition between Team USA and Team Canada, then make an official prediction for the game. We will then take a look at each team's roster and full Olympic schedule, as well as all 12 teams' odds to win gold.\n\nAs of right Tuesday afternoon, no odds have been made available for this exhibition match in Vegas. Sportsbooks probably don't want to take on too much liability with a friendly USA Showcase match, especially so early in the summer when nobody quite knows what kind of usage certain stars will see.\n\nThe U.S. and Canada top the sportsbooks' odds to win the 2024 Olympics, so it stands to reason that neither USA head coach Steve Kerr nor Canadian coach Jordi Fernandez want to give away too much strategy weeks before the actual Olympic games begin. How these squads play Wednesday could very well differ from how they plan at the end of July and beginning of August.\n\nThat said, expect Team USA to still run the show. This team serves as one of the better rosters ever constructed in Olympic hoops, and the U.S. has a reputation to uphold with 16 gold medals including one for each of the past four summer games (Tokyo 2020, Rio 2016, London 2012, Beijing 2008). Once the Olympic field of 12 was set following the FIBA last-chance qualifiers, the USA opened as a massive -390 favorite to win it all once again.\n\nThis USA squad has the size to contend with big men like Serbia's Nikola Jokic and Greece's Giannis Antetokounmpo, perimeter defense and outside shooting to match those international focuses, and proven winners (with 16 combined NBA championships between the 12 players). Comparatively, Canada has very little size and just one player with an NBA championship ring -- Jamal Murray -- since Andrew Wiggins will not play this summer due to medical reasons.\n\nUSA checks every box, and it's tough to imagine this team losing even one game this summer. Even in a friendly exhibition game, this squad should come out on top thanks to size, sheer volume of talent on both ends of the floor, and incomparable depth. {"uri": "8217168227", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "14:46:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T14:46:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T14:45:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/fadeaway-world-nba/brandin-podziemski-and-trayce-jackson-davis-share-identical-all-time-team-usa-starting-5s/article_cbf85003-96a1-5afa-abd7-241cd9aa0c16.html", "title": "Brandin Podziemski And Trayce Jackson-Davis Share Identical All-Time Team USA Starting 5's", "body": "The Golden State Warriors guarded a complementary guard and big in the 2023 Draft, with Brandin Podziemski and Trayce Jackson-Davis turning out to be high-impact rookies and core future pieces. The pair shared their all-time starting five for Team USA and happened to name the same five players.\n\nPG: Stephen Curry\n\nSG: Michael Jordan\n\nSF: Kobe Bryant\n\nPF: LeBron James\n\nC: Shaquille O'Neal\n\nThe pair explained why both came up with this lineup.\n\nTrayce Jackson-Davis: \"We've got a dominant big and we've got a four-man who can play the point and pass the ball. We have the best shooter ever and we've got two of the best two-way players and the greatest mentalities ever. It's finished.\"\n\nBrandin Podziemski: \"I feel like it just makes sense... A little bit of everything\"\n\nThat is a phenomenal five-man lineup to use for an all-time Team USA team. While the names are more attractive than their actual production on the biggest stage, no national team lineup could beat these five in their prime.\n\nLeBron James has the third-most points in Team USA history (273) and could win his third Gold medal in Paris 2024. Michael Jordan's presence in the 1992 Dream Team is what allowed that team to transcend culture, with his influence catapulting USA Basketball to new levels.\n\nKobe Bryant has won one Gold medal, but Stephen Curry has never represented Team USA in the Olympics. Naturally, Podz and TJD had to mention their franchise superstar, but his inclusion based on history is the weakest.\n\nTwo notable omissions have to be mentioned when you talk about Team USA, namely Kevin Durant and Charles Barkley.\n\nDurant could become the greatest basketball Olympian by winning his fourth Gold medal in Paris this year, so his status in a list like this should be unquestionable. He's also the all-time points leader for the USA in international basketball with 435 points on 19.7 points per game.\n\nBarkley was the best player on the iconic 1992 Dream Team, with coach Chucky Daly featuring Barkley as the primary scorer due to his size and agility making him virtually impossible to guard. He averaged 16.3 points and 6.7 rebounds over that Olympic run.\n\nAlmost every all-time great American player has played for the national team since the 1990s, with their predecessors playing as collegiate athletes before being barred from competing in the Olympics as NBA players. In terms of all-time names, these five players are arguably the highest-profile players to have donned the jersey.\n\nEven with the achievements of Durant and Barkley, their status is not as high as the other five. Even though it's a Team USA starting five, it's almost impossible to make a 'bad' choice when it comes to an all-time list.\n\nBig Season Ahead For Podziemski And Jackson-Davis\n\nThe Golden State Warriors have seemingly avoided falling into flux by maneuvering Klay Thompson's departure into a sign-and-trade that landed them Buddy Hield and Kyle Anderson, along with the signing of De'Anthony Melton. But these are surrounding pieces behind a core that features Stephen Curry and the young stars on the team.\n\nPodziemski's emergence as a rookie probably allowed the Warriors to allow Klay Thompson to walk as a free agent, as Podz averaged 9.2 points, 5.8 rebounds, and 3.7 assists. He took the starting spot from Klay at points last season, so it's clear he'll retain that position to start the 2024-25 season, coming off an All-Rookie First Team nod.\n\nJackson-Davis seems to be the center for the future for the Warriors, falling to them with the 57th pick in the 2023 Draft. He averaged 7.9 points, 5.0 rebounds, and 1.1 blocks, giving the Warriors center insurance behind Kevon Looney for the first time in years. He should expect to play bigger minutes, but a starting role isn't penciled in especially if Draymond Green moves to being their full-time center.\n\nRelated: Ranking The Greatest USA Dream Teams Including The 2024 Avengers\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. {"uri": "2024-07-417861336", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:49:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:49:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:22:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://fadeawayworld.net/team-usa-bigs-make-statement-2024-paris-olympics", "title": "Team USA Bigs Want To Make A Statement At 2024 Paris Olympics", "body": "Team USA's big men are eager to make a statement at the 2024 Paris Olympics, and their comments reveal a determination to address past shortcomings. Last summer's World Cup team struggled with size and physicality, leading to significant losses. Anthony Davis, Bam Adebayo, and Joel Embiid are now poised to change that narrative, as reported by Joe Vardon of The Athletic.\n\nAnthony Davis highlighting the importance of addressing the team's weaknesses said:\n\n\"They feel like we got bullied last year.\"\n\nDavis, with his 7-6 wingspan and recent first-team All-Defense honor, is a crucial addition to bolster the team's interior presence. He emphasized the need to stop the bullying and set a new tone for Team USA. Davis finished the season averaging 24.6 points, 12.6 rebounds, and 2.1 blocks per game.\n\nEmbiid, standing at 7 feet and weighing about 280 pounds, brings immense scoring and defensive abilities. His career-high 34.7 points per game last season for the Philadelphia 76ers, along with 11.0 rebounds and 1.7 blocks, underscores his dominant presence on the court.\n\nBam Adebayo, although the shortest of the trio at 6-9, has proven his mettle as Team USA's starting center during the Tokyo Olympics.\n\n\"I feel like we will definitely set the tone early, no matter who is in the game.\"\n\nAdebayo, coming off a first-team All-Defense season, echoed the sentiment of toughness and resilience. He emphasized the importance of establishing dominance from the start.\n\nThe addition of these three defensive stalwarts aims to counteract the weaknesses exposed in the previous World Cup, where the U.S. was often out-muscled in the paint. Their presence is expected to transform Team USA's approach, focusing on physicality, rebounding, and interior defense.\n\nWith the first exhibition game against Canada approaching, the team is set to demonstrate their newfound strength. The trio of Davis, Embiid, and Adebayo, along with contributions from LeBron James and Kevin Durant, aim to redefine Team USA's identity, making them formidable contenders for the gold medal in Paris.\n\nAs Bam Adebayo aptly put it, \"You put a team like this together, and we play the right way, it's going to be hard to beat us.\"\n\nFrance Is The Only Team Which Can Match Up To Team USA\n\nFrance, with their towering defensive duo of Rudy Gobert and Victor Wembanyama, stands as the only team that can truly challenge Team USA at the 2024 Paris Olympics. Gobert, standing at 7-1, and the 7-5 rookie sensation Wembanyama, have both showcased their defensive prowess by finishing as the winner and runner-up for the NBA Defensive Player of the Year award this season.\n\nThe combination of Gobert and Wembanyama creates a formidable presence in the paint, capable of disrupting even the most potent offenses. Gobert's shot-blocking and rebounding abilities are well-documented, having anchored the Utah Jazz's defense for years and now with the Minnesota Timberwolves.\n\nHis experience and positioning make him a vital piece of France's defensive scheme. On the other hand, Wembanyama's unique blend of height, agility, and shot-blocking instinct adds a new dimension to the French defense. His ability to alter shots and protect the rim makes him a significant threat to any team attempting to score inside.\n\nOne of the critical advantages for France is the absence of the NBA's three-second rule in international play, allowing their big men to camp in the paint and deter any drives to the basket. This rule difference plays perfectly into the hands of France's defensive strategy, making it difficult for opponents to penetrate and score easy baskets.\n\nTeam USA, with its array of superstar talent, including LeBron James, Kevin Durant, and Stephen Curry, will need to be at their absolute best to overcome this defensive juggernaut.\n\nThe presence of Gobert and Wembanyama means that the Americans will have to rely heavily on their perimeter shooting and ball movement to find open shots. Penetrating the French defense will be a significant challenge, and Team USA's guards and wings will need to be precise and efficient in their execution.\n\nThe perimeter players for France, including seasoned veterans and rising stars, are also crucial in supporting their defensive anchors. Players like Evan Fournier and Nicolas Batum bring experience and versatility, capable of both scoring and defending at a high level. Their ability to stretch the floor and create opportunities will be vital for France's overall performance.\n\nFrance's combination of elite defense, anchored by Gobert and Wembanyama, and a solid supporting cast, positions them as the primary challengers to Team USA's quest for Olympic gold. The showdown between these two basketball powerhouses promises to be a thrilling and high-stakes battle on the global stage.\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. {"uri": "8217408250", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:39:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:39:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T17:38:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.nbcmiami.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/usa-basketball-jersey-number-rules-olympics/3356953/", "title": "Here's why NBA and WNBA stars wear different jersey numbers for Team USA", "body": "Michael Jordan made No. 23 iconic with the Chicago Bulls, but he never donned the number with Team USA.\n\nThe basketball legend instead wore No. 9 during his two Olympic runs, both of which resulted in gold medals. He sported the number in his Olympic debut in 1984 before he ever played in the NBA, and he returned to No. 9 as a member of the 1992 Dream Team.\n\nJordan isn't the only star American basketball player to switch up their jerseys at the Olympics. Jayson Tatum will not wear his Boston Celtics No. 0 in Paris this summer, nor will Steph Curry wear the No. 30 he reps with the Golden State Warriors. The same goes for Las Vegas Aces No. 22 A'ja Wilson and New York Liberty No. 30 Breanna Stewart.\n\nWhy do USA Basketball players switch up their jersey numbers in red, white and blue? Here's a look back at where the tradition started and what NBA and WNBA stars will sport in Paris.\n\nOld international basketball rules restricted players to Nos. 4-15 to make it easier on game officials to communicate with hand signals, per NBC Olympics' Nick Zaccardi.\n\nFIBA dropped the rule in 2014, but USA Basketball still uses Nos. 4-15 for its men's and women's teams to maintain a level of tradition.\n\nNot every USA Basketball player can wear their NBA or WNBA jersey number at the Olympics.\n\nOf course, not every Team USA player wears a jersey number between 4-15 on their professional team. Additionally, multiple members of an Olympic team could wear the same number in the pros.\n\nJust two players on the U.S. men's basketball team for the 2024 Olympics will wear their NBA jersey number in Paris: Anthony Edwards (No. 5) and Bam Adebayo (No. 13). Not a single player on the U.S. women's basketball team will do the same with their WNBA jerseys.\n\nTwo other countries joined the U.S. by only using Nos. 4-15 on their basketball rosters: Australia (men's and women's) and China (women's).", "source": {"uri": "nbcmiami.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC 6 South Florida"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8217365732", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:04:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:04:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T17:03:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4392156898975372, "url": "https://uinterview.com/videos/video-exclusive-u-s-mens-basketball-director-grant-hill-says-team-usa-has-a-target-on-their-backs/", "title": "VIDEO EXCLUSIVE: U.S. Men's Basketball Director Grant Hill Says Team USA 'Has A Target On Their Backs' - uInterview", "body": "Grant Hill, managing director of the USA Men's National Basketball Team, expressed optimism about the squad's prospects for the upcoming Paris Olympics, acknowledging the pressure of representing the nation on the global stage.\n\n\"Every USA basketball team has a target on their backs,\" Hill told uInterview at the Team USA Media Summit. \"We know we will be targeted, and teams will want to beat us.\"\n\nThe former NBA star emphasized that this pressure motivates the players selected for the team. \"That's what these guys want. They want that responsibility, they want that pressure, they want to be on that stage,\" Hill explained.\n\nTeam USA has dominated men's basketball at the Olympics, winning four consecutive gold medals since 2008. However, their supremacy faced challenges at the 2020 Tokyo Games, where they lost to France in the opening game before rallying to claim gold.\n\nHill, who took over as managing director in 2021, succeeding Jerry Colangelo, brings a wealth of experience to his role. A two-time Olympic gold medalist himself (1996, 2000), Hill had an illustrious 19-year NBA career that included seven All-Star selections.\n\nLooking ahead to Paris, Hill highlighted the caliber of players on the roster. \"This team has some incredible star power, players with incredible legacies,\" he said, without naming specific individuals.\n\nThe 51-year-old executive expressed excitement about the team's potential, stating, \"We look forward to coming together and seeing what our potential can be. And hopefully, that's greatness, and hopefully, that's gold.\"\n\nThe men's basketball tournament at the Paris Olympics is scheduled to begin on July 27, 2024. Team USA aims to secure its fifth consecutive gold medal.\n\nLeave a comment Cancel reply Read more about: Basketball Grant Hill Olympics", "source": {"uri": "uinterview.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "uInterview"}, "authors": [{"uri": "lauren_ramsey@uinterview.com", "name": "Lauren Ramsey", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grant_Hill", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Grant Hill"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_national_baseball_team", "type": "wiki", "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "United States"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_executive_officer", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Chief executive officer"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Summit_League", "type": "wiki", "https://uinterview.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/Grant_Hill.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9713463", "eventUri": "eng-9713463", "location": null, "extractedDates": null,
